{{Infobox company | name = Activ Solar GmbH | logo = Activ Solar.png | caption = | type = [[Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung]] | traded_as = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2008}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Vienna]] | location_country = [[Austria]] | area_served = [[Ukraine]] | key_people = Kaveh Ertefai (CEO)
Johann Harter (COO)
Mykhailo Cherevko (Director, Ukraine subsidiary) | industry = [[Photovoltaics]] | products = [[Polysilicon]] | services = Large-scale solar PV project development | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,400+ (2011; together with subsidiaries) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = Diamond Activ Solar GmbH
PJSC Semiconductor Plant
Activ Solar LLC (Ukraine) | homepage = {{URL|www.activsolar.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Activ Solar GmbH''', headquartered in Vienna, Austria was a developer of solar energy. It was engaged in the production of [[polycrystalline silicon]] (polysilicon) for the solar PV industry and the development of large-scale [[photovoltaic]] power stations in Ukraine. The company is a member of the [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.epia.org/membership/epia-members-directory.html |title=EPIA Members' Directory |publisher=[[European Photovoltaic Industry Association|EPIA]] |accessdate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127132456/http://www.epia.org/membership/epia-members-directory.html |archivedate=2011-11-27 }} {{cite web | url = http://www.photovoltaik-guide.de/activ-solar-wird-mitglied-von-epia-18111 | title = Activ Solar wird Mitglied von EPIA | publisher = photovoltaik-guide.de | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Activ Solar is a member of EPIA | language = German}} {{cite web | url = http://www.greentech-germany.com/activ-solar-wird-mitglied-von-epia-a24360 | title = Activ Solar wird Mitglied von EPIA | publisher = greentech-germany.com | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Activ Solar is a member of EPIA | language = German}} {{cite web | url = http://www.ep-photovoltaik.de/nc/aktuelles/nachrichten/detail/artikel/activ-solar-wird-epia-mitglied/ | title = Activ Solar wird Epia Mitglied | publisher = ep-photovoltaik.de | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Activ Solar will be member of EPIA | language = German}} In February 2016, it filed for insolvency. {{cite news | url = http://diepresse.com/home/wirtschaft/economist/4922854/Grosste-Pleite_UkraineFirma-Activ-Solar-mit-Sitz-in-Wien-pleite?_vl_backlink=/home/wirtschaft/economist/index.do | title = Größte Pleite: Ukraine-Firma Activ Solar mit Sitz in Wien pleite | newspaper = [[Die Presse]] | agency = [[Austria Press Agency|APA]] | date = 2016-02-10 | accessdate = 2016-02-16 |trans-title=Biggest defeat: Ukraine company Activ Solar, headquartered in Vienna broke | language = German}} ==Operations== ===Polysilicon production=== Activ Solar produced high-purity [[polysilicon]] at its subsidiary ''PJSC Semiconductor Plant'', located in [[Zaporizhia]], Ukraine. The production of semiconductor materials at the original Zaporizhia Titan and Magnesium Plant dates back to 1935. The facility formed the foundation of PJSC Semiconductor Plant, which began production of semiconductor-grade polysilicon in 1964. It was separated from the Zaporizhia Titan and Magnesium Plant in 2002. {{cite news | url = http://www.ukrrudprom.com/news/Andrey_Klyuev_priobrel_Zaporogskiy_zavod_poluprovodnikov.html | script-title=ru:Андрей Клюев приобрел завод полупроводников | work = UkrRudProm | publisher = Solar Media Limited | date = 2009-02-03 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Andriy Klyuyev acquired semiconductor plant | language = Russian}} The plant was historically also the only manufacturer of high-purity [[trichlorosilane]] in the [[Soviet Union]]. After comprehensive refurbishment and modernization, PJSC Semiconductor Plant reached an annual capacity of 2,500 metric tons of polysilicon and 27,000 metric tons of [[trichlorosilane]] (HCl3Si). The facility produces ~20 metric tons per annum of [[monocrystalline silicon]] using legacy equipment with a plan to expand to ~400 metric tons per annum. The factory also produces silicon [[tetrachloride]] (SiCl4), [[hydrogen]], [[nitrogen]] and [[hydrochloric acid]]. {{cite news | url = http://ua-energy.org/en/post/8309 | title = Johann Harter: We will construct one of the largest PV power stations in the world | publisher = Ukrainian Energy | date = 2011-06-15 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} ===Solar PV project development=== Activ Solar developed large-scale solar photovoltaic installations. As of November 2012, it had developed six {{cite news | url = http://www.uaenergy.com.ua/c225758200614cc9/0/2cc60339e9279544c2257ab0003cd8e4 | title =Мощность солнечных парков Activ Solar превысила 300 МВт |trans-title=Activ Solar's power solar parks exceeded 300 MW | language =Russian | work = UA Energy | date = 2012-08-11 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} solar PV power stations with 313.35 [[megawatt]]s (MW) of installed [[nameplate capacity|capacity]] on the [[Crimean Peninsula]] and [[Odessa Oblast|Odessa region]]. [[File:RodnikovoyeSolarPark.jpg|left|thumb|Rodnikovoye Solar Park (7,5 MW)]] [[File:Okhotnykovosolarpark.jpg|right|thumb|[[Okhotnykovo Solar Park]] (82,65 MW)]] The company constructed Ukraine's first large-scale Photovoltaic power plant 7.5 MW Rodnikovoye Solar Park in February 2011. The power plant was built near the town of Rodnikovoye, about {{convert|3|km}} away from [[Simferopol]], the capital of the [[Autonomous Republic Crimea|Autonomous Republic of Crimea]]. The total number of solar modules installed reached about 33,800 on a total surface area of approximately {{convert|15|ha}}. {{cite news | url = http://www.euronews.net/2011/06/24/ukrainian-solar-plant-signals-green-power-drive | title = Ukrainian solar plant signals green power drive | work = [[Euronews]] | date = 2011-06-24 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} {{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13926984 | title =Ukraine hopes solar power will cut its energy imports | work = UA Energy | date = 2012-06-27 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} In October 2011, Activ Solar commissioned one of the world's largest solar power stations, the 80 MW [[Okhotnykovo Solar Park]]. Installation consisting of approximately 360,000 ground-mounted PV-modules and spanning over {{convert|160|ha}} able to generate 100 GWh of electricity per year enough to meet the energy needs of about 20,000 households. {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-tech.org/news/mission_accomplished_for_activ_solar_final_phase_of_ukraine_solar_plant_com | title = Mission accomplished for Activ Solar: final phase of Ukraine solar plant completed | work = PV Tech | publisher = Solar Media Limited | first = Nilima | last = Choudhury | date = 2011-10-26 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-tech.org/news/activ_solar_connects_first_phase_of_80mw_ukrainian_solar_plant_to_grid | title = Activ Solar completes first phases of 80MW Ukrainian solar plant | work = PV Tech | publisher = Solar Media Limited | first = Chris | last = Whitmore | date = 2011-08-09 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} {{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/29/solar-plant-ukraine-natural-energy_n_941274.html | title = Solar Power Plant In Ukraine | work = The Huffington Post | publisher = HPMG News | date = 2011-08-29 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} {{cite news |url=http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2011/kw23/activ-solar-commissions-20-mw-pv-plant-in-ukraine-largest-in-eastern-europe.html |title=Activ Solar commissions 20 MW PV plant in Ukraine, largest in Eastern Europe |work=SolarServer |date=2011-06-09 |publisher=HPMG NewsHeindl Server GmbH |accessdate=2012-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621224407/http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2011/kw23/activ-solar-commissions-20-mw-pv-plant-in-ukraine-largest-in-eastern-europe.html |archivedate=2012-06-21 }} [[File:Perovosolarstation.jpg|thumb|[[Perovo Solar Park]] (105,56 MW)]] [[File:Mityaevo Solar Park 2012.jpg|thumb|left|Mityaevo Solar Park (31,55 MW)]] [[File:STAROKOZACHE SOLAR STATION 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Starokozache Solar Park]] (42,95 MW)]] In December 2011, Activ Solar completed the 105.56 MW [[Perovo Solar Park]], amongst the largest in the world. Built in record-setting time, Perovo's more than 440,000 crystalline solar PV modules can produce as much as 132.5 GWh) of electricity per year, enough to meet the needs of Simferopol. More than 105,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions will be avoided. {{cite news | url = http://cleantechnica.com/2011/12/29/activ-solar-commissions-100-plus-mw-perovo-solar-pv-station-in-ukraines-crimea | title = Activ Solar Commissions 100-Plus MW Perovo Solar PV Station in Ukraine’s Crimea | work = Cleantechnica | date = 2011-12-29 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-tech.org/project_focus/perovo_solar_power_station_ukraine | title = Perovo Solar Power Station, Ukraine | work = PV Tech | publisher = Solar Media Limited | first = Chris | last = Whitmore | date = 2012-01-03 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} {{cite news |url=http://www.pvresources.com/PVPowerPlants/Top50.aspx |title=Large-Scale Photovoltaic Power Plants |work=Pvresources |accessdate=2012-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160101000000/http://www.pvresources.com/PVPowerPlants/Top50.aspx |archivedate=2016-01-01 }} In April 2012, Activ Solar finished work on its fourth large-scale project, 31.55 MW station located in the village of Mityaevo in Crimea. The ground-mounted power station houses over 134,000 polycrystalline modules, installed in double rows and connected by over {{convert|440|km}} of cable, and able to generate approximately 40 GWh of electricity per annum enough to supply 8,000 households. {{cite news | url = http://eqmaglive.com/index.php?option=com_multicategories&view=article&id=7830:activ-solar-completes-3155-mw-mityaevo-solar-pv-power-station#.UMdp56V7QaY | title = Activ Solar Completes 31.55 MW Mityaevo Solar PV Power Station | work = EQ INTERNATIONAL | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} In July 2012, Activ Solar completed 42.95 MW Starkozache power plant in Odessa Oblast. It is installed over a surface of {{convert|80|ha}} and consists of 185,952 multi-crystalline solar modules and 41 inverters. The solar plant is able to generate 54.106 GWh of electricity per annum, enough to supply approximately 11,000 households and saves up to 44,000 tons of {{CO2|link=yes}} emissions per year. {{cite news | url = http://eqmaglive.com/index.php?option=com_multicategories&view=article&id=10863:activ-solar-completes-final-phase-of-the-starokozache-solar-power-station-odessa-region&catid=97:europe#.UMW6coOyAbw | title = Activ Solar Completes Final Phase Of The Starokozache Solar Power Station, Odessa Region | work = EQ INTERNATIONAL | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} {{cite news | url = http://www.solarindustrymag.com/e107_plugins/content/content.php?content.10699#.UMW6vIOyAbw | title = Activ Solar Completes 43 MW Solar Project In Ukraine | work = Solar Industry | publisher = Solar Media Limited | date = 2012-07-10 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} [[File:Dunayskaya solar station 2012.jpg|left|thumb|Dunayskaya Solar Park (43,14 MW)]] [[File:Dunayskaya solar station 2013.jpg|left|thumb|Activ Solar’s “Have a sunny day!” sign on Dunayskaya SPP]] In November 2012, Activ Solar completed the second phase of the 43.14 MW Dunayskaya Solar Power Station in Odessa Oblast. Located in the southern part of Odessa Oblast, it comprises 182,380 multicrystalline photovoltaic modules, 40 inverter stations and around {{convert|645|km}} of cable. {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-tech.org/news/activ_solar_completes_43mwp_pv_power_plant_in_ukraine | title = Activ Solar completes 43MWp PV power plant in Ukraine | work = PV Tech | publisher = Solar Media Limited | first = Mark | last = Osborne | date = 2012-11-06 | accessdate = 2012-12-11}} In February 2013, Activ Solar announced the start of commissioning of the 29.3 MW Voznesensk Solar Power Station in [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv region]]. {{cite news | url = http://about.bnef.com/bnef-news/activ-solar-starts-modules-at-sun-power-plant-in-ukraine/ | title = Activ Solar Starts Modules at Sun Power Plant in Ukraine | work = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 2013-02-27 | accessdate = 2012-03-19}} Voznesensk Solar Power Station consists of 121,176 multicrystalline solar modules and 27 inverter stations installed on a four-row mounting system. The power station's electricity production capacity totals 35,000 megawatt hours per annum and will save over 28,000 tons of {{CO2}} per annum. [[File:LIMANSKAYA SOLAR POWER.JPG|left|thumb|Lymanske Solar Park (43.4 MW)]] In April 2013, Activ Solar announced the commissioning of the 43.4 MW Lymanske Solar Power Plant in the south-western part of [[Odessa Oblast]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-tech.org/news/activ_solar_installs_127.5mw_of_pv_capacity_in_q1_2013 | title = Activ Solar installs 127.5MW of PV capacity in Q1 2013 | work = PV Tech | publisher = Solar Media Limited | date = 2013-04-04 | accessdate = 2013-06-19}} It comprises 181.192 multicrystalline, installed in one row and connected by over 41 inverter stations. The solar plant will generate 59.415 GWh of electricity per annum and will save up to 46.179 tons of {{CO2}} emissions per year. {{cite news | url = http://www.activsolar.com/products/pv-project-development/project-references | title = PV PROJECT REFERENCES | work = Activ Solar official site | accessdate = 2013-06-19}} ===Research and development=== [[File:Solar Wing in Le Bourget 2011.JPG|thumb|Activ Solar and Diamond Aircraft Industries exhibited a prototype aircraft wing with embedded solar panels at the Paris Air Show 2011 Le Bourget]] Activ Solar owned a research and development joint-venture with [[Diamond Aircraft Industries]] with an aim to develop products and applications for the photovoltaic industry. Diamond Activ Solar exhibited a solar aircraft wing at the Paris Air Show 2011 [[Paris Air Show|Le Bourget]]. {{cite news | url = http://solareview.blogspot.com/2011/07/activ-solar-diamond-aircraft-industries.html | title = Activ Solar и Diamond Aircraft Industries разработали прототип авиационного крыла со встроенными солнечными батареями | publisher = | agency = [[Interfax-Ukraine]] | date = 2011-07-21 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Activ Solar and Diamond Aircraft Industries developed a prototype aircraft wing with embedded solar panels | language = Russian}} ==Awards and recognitions== In February 2011, Rodnikovoye Solar Park was recognized as one of the winners for the "Best Project in the Field of Renewable Energy" by Top-100. {{cite news | url = http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/publish/article?art_id=244066222 | script-title=ru:В 2011 году на энергоэффективность запланировано почти 600 млн. грн. бюджетных средств | newspaper = Урядовий портал | date = 2011-02-15 | accessdate = 2012-12-09 | language =Russian}} Energy Efficiency Award 2011, organized and conducted by the State Agency on Energy Efficiency and Energy Saving of Ukraine (SAEE). In December 2011, 82.65 MWp Ohotnikovo Solar Power Station was recognized as the "Best project in the field of Renewable Energy" by Green Awards Ukraine, {{cite news |url=http://www.greenawards.info/ua/imidzhevyij-blok/pobediteli-2011.html |script-title=uk:Переможці 2011 |newspaper=GreenAwards-Ukraine |date=2011-12-15 |accessdate=2012-12-09 |language=Ukrainian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121223105225/http://www.greenawards.info/ua/imidzhevyij-blok/pobediteli-2011.html |archivedate=2012-12-23 }} contest where the jury is presented by the leading experts in the field of environmental technologies and practices of the European level, public opinion leaders and representatives of influential international organizations and institutions. ==Ownership== Activ Solar was controlled by Ukraine's former first deputy prime minister [[Andriy Klyuyev]] and his brother [[Serhiy Klyuyev]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/104860/ | title = Klyuyev's solar energy companies shine brightly | newspaper = [[Kyiv Post]] | first = Yuriy | last = Onyshkiv | date = 2011-05-20 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} {{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/news/business/bus_focus/detail/77091 | title = Green energy struggles to grow | newspaper = [[Kyiv Post]] | first = Oksana | last = Faryna | date = 2010-08-05 | accessdate = 2011-11-28}} {{cite news | url = http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/11/12/5565415/ | script-title=uk:"Україна для людей": 370 мільйонів державної підтримки - для двох донецьких родин | newspaper = [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] | first = Sergey | last = Leshchenko | date = 2010-12-11 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title="Ukraine for the People": 370 million of state support - for two families from Donetsk | language = Ukrainian}} {{cite news |url= http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/60108.html |title=NERC to issue solar power generation licenses to three Crimea Solar companies |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2017-06-26}} {{cite news | url = http://derstandard.at/1316390231527/Solarpark-aus-Oesterreich-Gruener-Tarif-lockt-Investoren-auf-die-Krim | title = Grüner Tarif lockt Investoren auf die Krim | newspaper = [[Der Standard]] | first = Verena | last = Diethelm | date = 2011-09-22 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Green tariff attracts investors to the Crimea | language = German}} CEO of Activ Solar, Kaveh Ertefai, is Serhiy Klyuyev's son-in-law. Bogdan Klyuyev, son of Andriy Klyuyev, is a business developer manager of Activ Solar LLC (Ukraine). {{cite news | url =http://rubenius.com/assets/docs/Bloomberg_New_Energy_Finance_article.pdf | title = Activ Solar Completes First Large Ukrainian Solar Project | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | format = PDF | date = 2011-10-11 | accessdate = 2011-12-03}} {{cite news | url = http://www.kommersant.ua/doc/1804818/ | script-title=ru:НКРЭ повысила "зеленые" тарифы на электроэнергию | newspaper = Kommersant Ukraina | first = Oleg | last = Gavrish | date = 2011-10-28 | accessdate = 2011-12-05 |trans-title=NERC increased "green" electricity tariffs | language = Russian}} According to ''[[Kyiv Post]]'', Klyuyev's companies are registered at the same building where Activ Solar has its representative office in Ukraine. According to the report by ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]'', Solar Activ was founded by Slav Beteiligung GmbH, owned by Slav AG, investment firm of by brothers Kluyevs. In late 2008, the ownership was transferred to Kaveh Ertefay. In July 2009, ownership was transferred to P&A Corporate Trust. {{cite news | url = http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2011/10/21/6693989/ | script-title=uk:Офшорний дах для Януковича та Клюєва | newspaper = [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] | first = Sergey | last = Leshchenko | date = 2011-10-21 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Offshore roof for Yanukovych and Klyuyev | language = Ukrainian}} According to a British register, P&A Corporate Trust owns British firm Blythe (Europe) Ltd, which owns 35% of company [[Tantalit]] which was the nominal owner of the residence of President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] at [[Mezhyhirya Residence|Mezhyhirya]]. {{cite news | url = http://www.epravda.com.ua/news/2011/11/3/304255/ | script-title=uk:"Сонячна імперія" Клюєва отримала додаткових 20 мегават | newspaper = Ekonomichna Pravda | date = 2011-11-03 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Klyuyev's "Solar Empire" received additional 20 MW | language =Ukrainian}} According to the company register, in 2011 Activ Solar was 100% owned by Liechtenstein-registered P&A Corporate Trust. {{cite news | url = http://www.wirtschaftsblatt.at/archiv/470946/index.do | title = Milliarden-Deal in der Ukraine | newspaper = [[Wirtschaftsblatt]] | date = 2011-05-05 | accessdate = 2011-11-28 |trans-title=Billion deal in Ukraine | language =German}} {{cite news |url=http://www.firmenabc.at/activ-solar-gmbh_EHdS |title=ACTIV Solar GmbH in Wien |publisher=Firmen ABC |accessdate=2011-11-28 |trans-title=|language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111205154107/http://www.firmenabc.at/activ-solar-gmbh_EHdS |archivedate=2011-12-05 }} According to the company, shareholders of the company were European institutional and private investors. According to Johann Harter (COO), all shareholders were Austrian institutional and private investors and there were no Ukrainian private investors or companies associated with the Ukraine among the shareholders. {{cite news |url=http://www.investgazeta.net/kompanii-i-rynki/jogan-harter-solnce---tozhe-161133 |script-title=ru:Йоган Хартер: Солнце - тоже бизнес |first=Igor |last=Goshovskiy |newspaper=Invest Gazeta |accessdate=2011-11-29 |trans-title=Johann Harter: Sun - also a business |language=Russian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526191041/http://www.investgazeta.net/kompanii-i-rynki/jogan-harter-solnce---tozhe-161133 |archivedate=2012-05-26 }} According to Kave Ertefay (CEO), 50% of the shares belonged to investors from Austria and the rest of the EU. [[Interfax-Ukraina]] agency reported that controlling stake in Activ Solar belongs to Christian Dries, the owner of [[Diamond Aircraft Industries]], and the rest is owned by the management of the company. {{cite news |url=http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/exclusive/108567/ |title=Exclusive Christian Dries: I have a controlling stake in Activ Solar |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraina]] |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2012-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001224136/http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/exclusive/108567/ |archivedate=2012-10-01 }} At the beginning of 2016, the sole owner of the company was Viennese lawyer Stefan Benesch. ==Insolvency== On 1 April 2014, Activ Solar stopped operations of its solar power plants in Crimea due to unclear legal situation after [[annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation]]. While Ukrainian authorities stopped paying [[feed-in tariff]] for Crimean solar plants, Crimean and Russian authorities also refused to pay it. {{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/activ-solar-considers-aksionovs-statement-on-its-crimean-projects-groundless-348024.html | title = Activ Solar considers Aksionov's statement on its Crimean projects groundless | newspaper = [[Kyiv Post]] | agency = [[Interfax-Ukraine]] | date = 2014-05-15 | accessdate = 2014-05-16 | id = {{subscription required}}}} In spring 2015, Crimean solar plants were seized by Russian banks to cover outstanding loans of Activ Solar. {{cite news | url = http://www.pv-magazine.com/news/details/beitrag/russian-banks-set-to-seize-crimean-solar-power-plants_100019001/#axzz4Auk3XmC0 | title = Russian banks set to seize Crimean solar power plants | work = PV Magazine | date = 2015-04-13 | accessdate = 2016-02-16 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150717064508/http://www.pv-magazine.com/news/details/beitrag/russian-banks-set-to-seize-crimean-solar-power-plants_100019001/ | archive-date = 2015-07-17 | dead-url = no}} {{cite news | url = http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2702566 | title = Крымское солнце закатилось в госбанки. Без зеленого тарифа им долги не вернуть | newspaper = [[Kommersant]] | first1 = Anastasia | last1 = Fomicheva | first2 = Natalia | last2 = Skorlygina | first3 = Vadim | last3 = Nikiforov | date = 2015-04-06 | accessdate = 2016-02-25 |trans-title=Crimean sun had gone down to the state-owned banks. Without a green tariff they do not return the debt | language = Russian}} In November 2015, the [[China National Building Material Company]] (CNBM) received a clearance to buy the Activ Solar's subsidiary operating ten solar parks located in [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv]] and [[Odessa Oblast|Odessa]] oblasts. {{cite news | url = http://renewables.seenews.com/news/chinas-cnbm-gets-nod-to-buy-activ-solar-parks-in-ukraine-500379 | title = China's CNBM gets nod to buy Activ Solar parks in Ukraine | first = Tsvetomira | last = Tsanova | agency = SeeNews | date = 2015-11-05 | accessdate = 2016-02-16}} According to the company, it had controlled these power stations since mid-2014 as collateral of its €160 million loan to Activ Solar. {{cite news | url = http://nv.ua/publications/razbor-ieroglifov-kitajskaja-goskompanija-pretenduet-na-solnechnye-elektrostantsii-kljuevyh-a-deputaty-urezajut-im-tarif-96294.html | title = Разбор иероглифов. Китайская госкомпания претендует на солнечные электростанции Клюевых, а депутаты урезают им тариф | newspaper = Novoye Vremya | first = Ivan | last = Verstyuk | date = 2016-02-10 | accessdate = 2016-02-25 |trans-title=Examination of hieroglyphs. Chinese state-owned company applies for solar power stations of Klyuyevs, deputies cut their tariff | language = Russian}} CNBM s also interested to buy the Zaporizhia Semiconductor Plant. {{cite news | url = http://uatoday.tv/politics/the-sunset-of-klyuyev-empire-who-will-take-over-assets-of-disgraced-brothers-589397.html | title = Sunset of Klyuyev Empire: Who will take over assets of disgraced brothers? | first = Dmytro | last = Ryasnyi | agency = Ukraine Today | date = 2016-02-11 | accessdate = 2016-02-16}} Investigation had been launched concerning the Ukrainian state credit grant to the Zaporizhia Semiconductor Plant in 2010. In October 2015, the Ukrainian court ordered repayment of the €57 million grant. As a result, Activ Solar filed for reorganisation in the Commercial Court of Vienna on 10 February 2016. The company explained this move with challenging market conditions in Ukraine due to the economic and political crisis in the region, which affected production in the Zaporizhia Semiconductor Plant. {{cite press release | url = http://www.activsolar.com/media/press-releases/activ_solar_files_for_reorganisation_in_austria | title = Activ Solar files for reorganisation in Austria | work = Activ Solar official site | date = 2016-02-10 | accessdate = 2016-02-24}} For that time, Activ Solar's debt had amounted €503.4 million while its assets accounted €18.69 million. {{cite news | url = http://www.be24.at/blog/entry/702109/activ-solar-baut-megainsolvenz-mit-mehr-als-einer-halben-milliarde-verbindlichkeiten | title = Activ Solar baut Megainsolvenz mit mehr als einer halben Milliarde (!) Verbindlichkeiten | newspaper = Börse Express | first = Paul Christian | last = Jezek | date = 2016-02-12 | accessdate = 2016-02-25 |trans-title=Activ Solar builds mega bankruptcy with more than half a billion (!) liabilities | language = German}} The company proposed a two-years restructuring plan with 20% of its debts repayment. Attorney Ute Toifl was appointed as an insolvency administrator. {{cite news | url = http://wirtschaftsblatt.at/home/nachrichten/oesterreich/wien/4922719/Megapleite_Activ-Solar-hat-eine-halbe-Milliarde-Euro-Schulden | title = Megapleite: Activ Solar hat eine halbe Milliarde Euro Schulden | newspaper = [[WirtschaftsBlatt]] | agency = [[Austria Press Agency|APA]] | date = 2016-02-10 | accessdate = 2016-02-25 |trans-title=Mega bust: Activ Solar has half a billion euros of debt | language = German}} Also the Zaporizhia Semiconductor Plant went into bankrupt. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Austria|Energy}} * {{official website}} [[Category:Solar energy companies]] [[Category:Energy companies of Austria]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of Ukraine]] [[Category:Energy companies of Ukraine]] [[Category:Corruption in Ukraine]]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Albanophile]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Ethnic Macedonians burning the Albanian flag.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A mob of [[ethnic Macedonians]] burning the Albanian flag]] --> {{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Anti-Albanian sentiment''' or '''Albanophobia''' is discrimination or prejudice towards [[Albanians]] as an ethnic group, described in countries with large Albanian population as immigrants, especially [[Greece]] and [[Italy]] though in Greece the sentiment has existed mainly in the post-communist Albania era where many criminals escaped to Greece.<ref name="books.google.com">By Russell King, Nicola Mai, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=nNHCqrp1IP4C&pg=PA114 Out of Albania: from crisis migration to social inclusion in Italy]'', pp 114</ref><ref>Georgios Karyotis, [http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/hellenicObservatory/pdf/2nd_Symposium/Georgios_Karyotis_paper.pdf ''Irregular Migration in Greece''], pp. 9</ref><ref>By Russell King, Nicola Mai, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=nNHCqrp1IP4C&pg=PA114 Out of Albania: from crisis migration to social inclusion in Italy]'', pp 21</ref>
A similar term used with the same denotation is ''anti-albanianism''<ref>By Michael Mandelbaum, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=qoHQ3OgU8bMC&pg=PA234&dq=anti-albanianism#v=onepage&q=anti-albanianism&f=false The new European diasporas: national minorities and conflict in Eastern Europe]'', 234</ref> used in many sources similarly with ''albanophobia'', although its similarities and/or differences are not defined.
Its opposite is Albanophilia.
==Origins and forms== The term "Albanophobia" was coined by [[Anna Triandafyllidou]] on a report analysis called ''Racism and Cultural Diversity in the Mass Media'' published in 2002.<ref name="books.google.com"/> Although, the first recorded usage of the term comes from 1982 in ''The South Slav journal, Volume 8'' by Albanian author [[Arshi Pipa]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=axoWAQAAMAAJ&q=Albanophobia&dq=Albanophobia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YQDBT5aLHJPZ4QT6obiiAQ&redir_esc=y The South Slav journal, Volume 8] page 21, [[Arshi Pipa]] (1982).</ref> The report by Triandafyllidou represented Albanian migrants in Greece<ref>By Anna Triandafyllidou, ''[http://fra.europa.eu/fraWebsite/attachments/MR-CH4-4-Greece.pdf Racism and Cultural Diversity In the Mass Media]'', Robert Schuman Centre, European University Institute, pp. 149</ref> and was followed by other researchers like Karyotis in Greece and Mai in Italy. The hyphenated form "Albano-phobia" is used on some references (including Triandafyllidou), apparently with the same meaning.
Albanian stereotypes that formed amid the creation of an independent Albanian state, and stereotypes that formed as a result of massive immigrations from Albania and Kosovo during the 1980s and '90s, although they may differ from each other, are still both considered Albanophobic and anti-Albanian by many authors such as Triandafyllidou, Banac, Karyotis.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
Albanophobia signifies a wider range of concepts that could be roughly grouped in two main categories:{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} * '''Albanophobia as xenophobic''' - referring to stereotypes in countries with a considerable number of Albanian immigrants like Greece, Italy, Switzerland, Germany, France and United States. * '''Albanophobia as nationalistic''' - referring to stereotypes in countries with active disputes with Albanian ethnicity in the region, most commonly [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|ex-Yugoslav countries]] (Macedonia, Serbia, Montenegro). The second is more likely to be associated with the term ''anti-albanianism''.{{failed verification|date=October 2011}}
== Greece == The stereotype by some in [[Greece]] of Albanians as criminal and degenerate in Greece has been subject of a 2001 study by the [[International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights]] (IHFHR) and by the [[Fundamental Rights Agency|European Monitoring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia]] (EUMC).<ref name="unhcr.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/403dd1f50.html|title=Refworld - Greece: Treatment of ethnic Albanians|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|work=Refworld|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="EUMC Nov. 2001, 25, 38 n. 85">(EUMC Nov. 2001, 25, 38 n. 85)</ref> It is considered that prejudices and mistreatment of Albanians to be still present in Greece.<ref name="unhcr.org"/> According to a 2002 statement of the IHFUR, the Albanians are the most likely ethnic group in Greece to be killed by Greek law enforcement officials.<ref name="unhcr.org"/> In addition, the EUMC singles out ethnic Albanians as principal targets of racism. Furthermore, the EUMC found that undocumented Albanian migrants "experience serious discrimination in employment, particularly with respect to the payment of wages and social security contributions".<ref name="unhcr.org"/><ref name="unhcr.org"/><ref name="EUMC Nov. 2001, 25, 38 n. 85"/> Albanians are often pejoratively named and or called by Greeks as "Turks", represented in the expression ''"[[Turco-Albanians|Turkalvanoi]]"''.<ref name = Millas>Millas, Iraklis (2006). "Tourkokratia: History and the image of Turks in Greek literature." South European Society & Politics. '''11'''. (1): 50. “The ‘timeless’ existence of the Other (and the interrelation of the Self with this Other) is secured by the name used to define him or her. Greeks often name as ‘Turks’ various states and groups—such as the Seljuks, the Ottomans, even the Albanians (''Turkalvanoi'')”.</ref><ref name = Megalommatis>Megalommatis, M. Cosmas (1994). ''Turkish-Greek Relations and the Balkans: A Historian's Evaluation of Today's Problems''. Cyprus Foundation. p. 28. “Muslim Albanians have been called “''Turkalvanoi''” in Greek, and this is pejorative.”</ref> Albanians in Greece are also classified in terms as "savage", while the Greeks view themselves as "civilised".<ref>Nitsiakos, Vassilis (2010). ''On the border: Transborder mobility, ethnic groups and boundaries along the Albanian-Greek frontier''. LIT Verlag. p. 65. "The few exchanges also bear the imprint of the above structural asymmetry and reflect the level of development of the two countries. While mainly agricultural and dairy products (drugs and weapons are a separate chapter) flow in from Albania, mostly uncontrollably, from Greece to Albania we have, in addition to money, a flow of a great gamut of material goods and products, from simple items of everyday use and consumption, to electrical equipment and cars. One may say that, whereas Albanian products represent “nature”, Greek ones represent “civilization”, a dichotomy that characterises the differences of the two groups from the point of view of the Greeks: Albanians are classified as “savage”, while Greeks as “civilized”, a fact that expresses, of course, the general racist attitude of the Greeks."</ref>
Prejudicial representations of Albanians and Albanian criminality (see [[Albanian mafia]]) by the Greek media is largely responsible for the social construction of negative stereotypes, in contrast to the commonly held belief that Greek society is neither [[xenophobic]] nor racist.<ref>[http://fra.europa.eu/fraWebsite/attachments/AR00_p2_EN.pdf Diversity and equality for Europe Annual Report 2000]. European Monitoring Centre of Racism and Xenophobia, p. 38</ref>
In March 2010, during an official military parade in [[Athens]], [[Greek people|Greek]] soldiers chanted "They are Skopians, they are Albanians, we will make new clothes out of their skins". The Civil Protection Ministry of Greece reacted to this by suspending the coast guard officer who was in charge of the parade unit, and pledged to take tough action against the unit's members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/index.php?aType=haber&ArticleID=56122|title=Greek soldiers chant anti-Turkish-Albanian slogans at military parade - Balkans - Worldbulletin News|work=World Bulletin|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
== Italy ==
Albanophobia in [[Italy]] is primarily related to the Albanian immigrants mainly young adults who are stereotypically seen as criminals, drug dealers and rapists.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Italophilia meets Albanophobia: Paradoxes of asymmetric assimilation and identity processes among Albanian immigrants in Italy|journal=Ethnic and Racial Studies|volume=32|pages=117–138|doi=10.1080/01419870802245034|year = 2009|last1 = King|first1 = Russell|last2=Mai|first2=Nicola|url=http://www.ssoar.info/ssoar/handle/document/13201|type=Submitted manuscript}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wantedinrome.com/articles/complete_articles.php?id_art=262 |title=Breaking the Albanian stereotype |access-date=28 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728145805/http://www.wantedinrome.com/articles/complete_articles.php?id_art=262 |archive-date=28 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Italian media provide a lot of space and attention to crimes committed by ethnic Albanians, even those just presumed.<ref name="Italy">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nNHCqrp1IP4C&pg=PA114&lpg=PA114&dq=Albanophobia+-forum#v=onepage&q=Albanophobia%20-forum&f=false|title=Out of Albania|publisher=|accessdate=9 May 2015|isbn=9781845455446|last1=King|first1=Russell|last2=Mai|first2=Nicola|year=2008}}</ref>
== Republic of Macedonia ==
[[File:Anti-Albanian_Inscription.png|thumb|right|250px|Anti-Albanian inscription written in Macedonian on a mosque, meaning "Death for [[Shqiptar]]s"]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Macdonian mob attacking an Albanian boy.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A mob of Macedonians attacking an Albanian boy in the March 2013 protests in Skopje, Macedonia]] --> Ethnic tensions have simmered in the [[Republic of Macedonia]] since the end of an [[Insurgency in the Republic of Macedonia|armed conflict in 2001]], where the ethnic Albanian [[National Liberation Army (Albanians of Macedonia)|National Liberation Army]] attacked the security forces of Macedonia with the goal of securing greater rights and autonomy for the ethnic Albanian minority.
The [[Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts|Macedonian Academy for Science and Art]] was accused of Albanophobia in 2009 after it published its first encyclopedia in which was claimed that the Albanian [[endonym]], [[Shqiptar#Use in South Slavic languages|Shqiptar]], means "highlander" and is primarily used by other Balkan peoples to describe Albanians, if used in South Slavic languages the endonym is considered derogatory by the Albanian community. The encyclopaedia also claimed that the Albanians settled the region in the 16th century.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=10&dd=01&nav_id=62079 |title=B92 - News - Macedonian encyclopedia pulled from shelves |work=B92 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213040201/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=10&dd=01&nav_id=62079 |archivedate=13 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name="BBC Alb">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/albanian/regionalnews/2009/09/090921_nayi_enciklopedia.shtml | title=Dënohet Enciklopedia maqedonase | publisher=BBC | accessdate=28 November 2012 | author=Rashidi, Nazim}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Macedonian_Encyclopedia_Sparks_Balkan_Ethnic_Row/1830215.html|title=Macedonian Encyclopedia Sparks Balkan Ethnic Row|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> Distribution of the encyclopedia was ceased after a series of public protests.
On 12 April 2012, five [[ethnic Macedonian]] civilians were shot dead allegedly by [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia|ethnic Albanian]] in an attack known as the [[Železarsko lake killings]]. On 16 April 2012, in the wake of the attack, an anti-Albanian protest was held in Skopje by ethnic Macedonians in which the participants were recorded chanting “a good [[Shqiptar]] is a dead Shqiptar” and “gas chambers for Shqiptars”.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RF2LprmkK4M&feature=player_embedded|title=Përleshje mes policisë dhe protestuesve në Shkup|date=16 April 2012|work=YouTube|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
On 1 March 2013 in [[Skopje]], a mob of ethnic Macedonians protested against the decision to appoint [[Talat Xhaferi]], an ethnic Albanian politician, as [[Minister of Defence]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://puls24.mk/makedonija/vesti/-privedeni-nekolkumina-ucesnici-vo-incidentot-pred-vlada | title=Приведени неколкумина учесници во инцидентот пред Влада | publisher=Puls 24 | accessdate=2 March 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302102850/http://puls24.mk/makedonija/vesti/-privedeni-nekolkumina-ucesnici-vo-incidentot-pred-vlada | archive-date=2 March 2013 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The protest turned violent when the mob started hurling stones and also attacking Albanian bystanders and police officers alike. The police reports 3 injured civilians, five injured police officers and much damage to private property. Although the city hospital reported treating five heavily injured Albanian men, two of which are on [[Intensive-care unit]]. During this protest part of the mob burned the Albanian flag.
On the 108th anniversary of the [[Congress of Manastir]] the museum of the Albanian alphabet in [[Bitola]] was vandalized, the windows and doors were broken. A poster with the words "Death to Albanians" and with the drawing of a lion cutting the heads of the Albanian double-headed eagle was placed on the front doors of the museum.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tv21.tv/mk/?p=109732 | title=ХУЛИГАНИ ГО ДЕМОЛИРАА МУЗЕЈОТ НА АЛБАНСКАТА АЗБУКА | publisher=21TV | accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> One week after this incident, on the day of the [[Albanian Declaration of Independence]] graffiti with the same messages, as those of the previous week, were placed on the directorate of [[Pelister National Park]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tv21.tv/web/?p=109822 | title=KËRCËNIM NË FESTËN E FLAMURIT 'VDEKJE SHQIPTARËVE' | publisher=TV-21 | accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref>
==Serbia== {{Main|Expulsion of the Albanians 1877–1878}}
The origins of anti-Albanian propaganda in Serbia started by the end of 19th century and the reason for this was the claims made by Serbian state on territories that were about to be controlled by Albanians after the collapse of the Ottoman Empire.<ref name="Banac">By [[Ivo Banac]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=KfqbujXqQBkC&pg=PT1&dq=ivo+banac&ei=OcjwSoXOCaCMygTNxNibAQ#v=snippet&q=anti-albanian&f=false The national question in Yugoslavia - origins, history, politics], page 293</ref> By the late nineteenth century, Albanians were being characterized by Serbian government officials as a “wild tribe” with “cruel instincts”.<ref name = Stefanović/> Others from Serbia's intelligentsia such as the geographer [[Jovan Cvijić]] referred to Albanians as being “the most barbarous tribes of Europe”.<ref name = Stefanović>Stefanović, Djordje (2005). "Seeing the Albanians through Serbian eyes: The Inventors of the Tradition of Intolerance and their Critics, 1804-1939." ''European History Quarterly''. '''35'''. (3): 472. “Officials of the Serbian Ministry of Foreign affairs described Albanians as a ‘wild tribe’ with ‘cruel instincts’…. A number of Serbian intellectuals and journalists added to the angry hate propaganda that seemed to culminate during the preparations for the Balkan Wars. Cvijić argued that ‘there is a general consensus that the Albanians are the most barbarous tribes of Europe’. Another intellectual described the Albanians as ‘European Indians’ and ‘lazy savages’.”</ref> Whereas politician [[Vladan Đorđević]] described Albanians as “modern [[Caveman|Troglodytes]]” and “prehumans, who slept in the trees” with still having “tails” in the nineteenth century.<ref>Gay, Peter (1993). ''The Cultivation of Hatred: The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud (The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud''). WW Norton & Company. p. 82. “In 1913, Dr. Vladan Djordjević, a Serbian politician and expert in public health, characterized Albanians as bloodthirsty, stunted, animal—like, so invincibly ignorant that they could not tell sugar from snow. These “modern Troglodytes” reminded him of “prehumans, who slept in the trees, to which they were fastened by their tails.” True, through the millennia, the human rail had withered away, but “among the Albanians there seem to have been humans with tails as late as the nineteenth century.””</ref> On the eve of the [[First Balkan War]] 1912, Serbian media had implemented a strong anti-Albanian campaign.<ref>Dimitrije Tucović, ''Srbija i Arbanija'' (in ''Izabrani spisi'', book II, pp. 56) Prosveta, Beograd, 1950.</ref>
In 1937, [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts|the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts]], and more specifically the noted Serb scholar and political figure [[Vaso Čubrilović]] (1897-1990) wrote a [[memorandum]] entitled "[[The Expulsion of the Albanians]]" which dealt with the methods that should be used to expel Albanians including: creating a "psychosis" by bribing clergymen to encourage the Albanians to leave the country, enforcing the law to the letter, secretly razing Albanian inhabited villages, ruthless application of all police regulations, ruthless collection of taxes and the payment of all private and public debts, the requisitioning of all public and municipal pasture land, the cancellation of concessions, the withdrawal of permits to exercise an occupation, dismissal from government, the demolition of Albanian cemeteries and many other methods.<ref>Ćubrilović, Vaso, [http://www.trepca.net/english/2006/the_expulsion_of_the_albanians_by_vaso_cubrilovic_memorandum_in_1937.html The Expulsion of the Albanians: Memorandum] 1937</ref>
During the end of the 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s, on some occasions activities undertaken by Serbian officials in Kosovo have been marked as ''albanophobic''.<ref>By Nebojša Popov, Drinka Gojković, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GkBmdCwHuDsC&pg=PA222&dq=albanophobia#v=onepage&q=albanophobia&f=false The road to war in Serbia: trauma and catharsis], pp. 222</ref>
The [[Role of the media in the Yugoslav Wars#Milošević's reign and control of media in Serbia|Serbian media during Milošević's era]] was known to espouse [[Serbian nationalism|Serb nationalism]] while promoting [[xenophobia]] toward the other ethnicities in [[Yugoslavia]]. Ethnic Albanians were commonly characterized in the media as anti-Yugoslav counter-revolutionaries, rapists, and a threat to the Serb nation.<ref>International Centre Against Censorship. "Forging War: The Media in Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina". ''International Centre Against Censorship, Article 19''. Avon, United Kingdom: Bath Press, May 1994. P55</ref> During the [[Kosovo War]], Serbian forces continually discriminating Kosovo Albanians:
{{quote|Throughout Kosovo, the forces of the [[Serbia and Montenegro|FRY]] and Serbia have harassed, humiliated, and degraded Kosovo Albanian civilians through physical and verbal abuse. Policemen, soldiers, and military officers have persistently subjected Kosovo Albanians to insults, racial slurs, degrading acts, beatings, and other forms of physical mistreatment based on their racial, religious, and political identification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/kosovo/more2.htm|title=Justice for Kosovo|author=American Public Media|publisher=|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>|War Crimes Indictment against Milosevic and others}}
A survey in Serbia showed that 40% of the Serbian population would not like Albanians to live in Serbia while 70% would not enter into a marriage with an Albanian individual the same exists in Albania towards Serbs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Drustvo/Raste-etnicka-distanca-medju-gradjanima-Srbije.lt.html|title=Raste etnička distanca među građanima Srbije|publisher=|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> In recent times, prominent politician [[Vuk Jeremić]] in his comments on [[Twitter]] about the rights and wrongs of the Kosovo dispute compared Albanians to the “evil [[Orc]]s” of the movie ''[[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey|The Hobbit]]''.<ref>Barlovac, Bojana (19 December 2012). "[http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/jeremic-compares-kosovo-issue-with-hobbit-movie Jeremic Likens Kosovars to 'Hobbit's' Evil Orcs]". ''Balkan Insight''. Retrieved 16 May 2015.</ref>
==Derogatory terms== *'''Shiptar''' – is a derogatory term for Albanians formed from their endonym ''shqiptar'' which is used by Balkan Slavic ethnicites such as the Serbs and Macedonians carrying pejorative meanings of a somewhat backward or aggressive person<ref name = Guzina>Guzina, Dejan (2003). "Kosovo or Kosova – Could it be both? The Case of Interlocking Serbian and Albanian Nationalisms". In Florian Bieber and Židas Daskalovski (eds.). ''Understanding the war in Kosovo''. Psychology Press. p.30.</ref> *'''Turk''' and '''Turco-Albanian''' – derogatory terms used by non-Albanians for ethnic Albanians who converted to Islam during the Ottoman rule.
==See also== * [[Massacres of Albanians in the Balkan Wars]] * [[Expulsion of Cham Albanians]] * [[Operation Horseshoe]] * [[Turco-Albanians]] * [[Discrimination]] * [[Racism]] * [[Xenophobia]] * [[Islamophobia]] * [[List of anti-ethnic and anti-national terms]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,IRBC,,GRC,4562d8b62,403dd1f50,0.html Treatment of ethnic Albanians in Greece] (UNHCR) * [http://www.drustvo-antropologov.si/AN/PDF/2008_2/Anthropological_Notebooks_XIV_2_Sievers.pdf Stephanie Schwandner-Sievers: Albanians, Albanianism and the strategic subversion of stereotypes] * [http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/italians/resources/Amiciprize/1998/Lamerica.html Italy's Conflicted Responses to Albanian Immigration and Lamerica's Transitive Historical Consciousness] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/14174116/Italophilia-Meets-Albanophobia Italophilia Meets Albanophobia] * [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/world/2004-09-09-greece-albania-march_x.htm USA Today - Anti-racism rally held after deadly soccer game] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090928040332/http://www.pescanik.net/content/view/125/105 Olivera Milosavljević: Stereotipi srpskih intelektualaca XX veka o Albancima] (Serbian) *[http://www.trepca.net/english/2006/the_expulsion_of_the_albanians_by_vaso_cubrilovic_memorandum_in_1937.html The Expulsion of the Albanians: Memorandum]
{{Cultural criticism}}
[[Category:Albanian people|Albanophobia]] [[Category:Discrimination]] [[Category:Anti-national sentiment]] [[Category:Racism]] [[Category:Anti-Albanian sentiment| ]]

'''Ngatikaura Ngati''' was a [[New Zealand]]-[[Tongan people|Tongan]] toddler who died of [[child abuse]] in January 2006. The deliberate judicial release of official [[autopsy]] photographs after the trial of his killers, for the subsequent distribution of those images on the Internet and for the subsequent debate about the images among government figures, including three successive [[Children's Commissioner Act 2003|Children's Commissioner]]s caused controversy that was the result of the tension between the desire for privacy and respect for victims of [[family violence]] and the need for publicity to motivate changes in public attitudes to family violence.
==Life and death== Ngati had been fostered to a cousin of his [[birth mother]] and was being raised in a [[Tongan language]] environment until shortly after his third birthday when he was returned to his birth mother, at her request. Maine Annabella Ngati, her partner, Teusila Fa'asisila, and their other children only spoke English. Within three months, Ngati was dead. Photos taken during the autopsy showed bruises from repeated beatings and weeping sores, one of which was "the size of a man's hand on his bottom."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10439204 |title=From happiness to hell |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=May 12, 2007 |accessdate=5 October 2012 |last=Binning |first=Elizabeth |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]}}</ref> Ngati and Fa'asisila were found [[Acquittal|not guilty]] of [[murder]], but guilty of [[manslaughter]], failing to provide a child with the necessities of life (medical care), and willful ill treatment of a child.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10445880 |title=Ex-carer tells boy's killers to hang themselves |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=15 June 2007|last=Vass |first=Beck |accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> In June, 2007, each was sentenced to eight and a half years in prison, with a minimum [[non-parole period]] of four years and eight months.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10446071 |title=Toddler's killers get 8 1/2 years |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=16 June 2007 |last=Vass |first=Beck |accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> Ngati gave birth to another child while in custody – which was placed with either foster or adoptive parents<ref name="birth">{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10772405 |title=Child killer gives birth in jail |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |last=Carroll |first=Joanne |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=11 December 2011 |quote='She has a lot of children and we believe she has even given birth to another child while on this prison sentence. That child has been fostered or adopted into the community,' the report said. |accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref> – and she was declined [[parole]] in November, 2011.<ref name="birth" /> Fa'asisila "came up for parole [in] December 2011" and "will be sent back to [[Tonga]] upon his release", but it is unclear whether he was in fact released.<ref>{{cite web|title=Teusila Ki Vaiola Fa'asisila |url=http://www.safe-nz.org.nz/Data/faasisilateusila.htm |work=Offender Database |publisher=Sensible Sentencing Trust |accessdate=6 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013190540/http://safe-nz.org.nz/Data/faasisilateusila.htm |archivedate=13 October 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Distribution of the images == {{quote box |quote = [It is] questionable whether publication of autopsy photographs of a young child beaten to death could ever be in the public interest. |source = Cindy Kiro, [[Children's Commissioner (New Zealand)|Children's Commissioner]], {{nowrap|March 2008}}<ref name="bsa" /> |width = 25% |align = right |qalign = left |quoted = 1 }}
After trial, in an unusual and controversial move, Auckland [[High Court of New Zealand|High Court]] Judge Graham Lang allowed the release of the autopsy photos into the public realm, and allowed New Zealand's [[TV One (New Zealand)]] (TVNZ) to film the autopsy photographs "so that they may give pause to those people who choose to ignore that their family members are being hurt".<ref name=bsa/> Since then, the images have been distributed through television, email and web, fueling controversy and debate along the way.
===Broadcast television=== TVNZ broadcast the images during a television news programme at 6pm on 6 August 2007. During that segment, Children's Commissioner Cindy Kiro is shown commenting that the public did not need to see these "graphic images to show them how badly damaged this child was."<ref name="bsa"/><ref name="tvnz 2007">{{cite web|title=Call to stand up against abuse|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/411425/1273282|publisher=[[TV One (New Zealand)]]|accessdate=16 October 2012|date=6 August 2007}}</ref> After the broadcast, she lodged a complaint with the [[Broadcasting Standards Authority]] (BSA), arguing that "[''One News''] had displayed a disregard for the rights of the young victim and exploitation of him by showing these photos". Calling the broadcast a "further abuse in death" of the child, Kiro said that it was "... questionable whether publication of autopsy photographs of a young child beaten to death could ever be in the public interest." Her complaint alleged violations of several of the BSA's standards, including "good taste and decency", "privacy", "fairness", "children's interests" and "violence". <ref name=bsa/> <!-- {{clear}} If moving the image, please participate in the discussion on the talk page. The 'clear', 'anchor' and 'file' tags should remain together, if possible. --> {{quote box |quote = [The Authority] recognises that news programmes will often contain "violent, disturbing or alarming material", and that broadcasters "should not falsify by omission, a world in which much violence and brutality occurs". |source = [[Broadcasting Standards Authority]], {{nowrap|March 2008}}<ref name="bsa"/> |width = 25% |align = right |qalign = left |quoted = 1 }} The complaint was investigated, but was "not upheld" on all counts.<ref name=DP-complaint-rejected/> With respect to "good taste and decency" the BSA acknowledged that "the autopsy images would have been distressing to some viewers. However, they conveyed the grim reality of child abuse in the context of [a news] item...."<ref name=bsa/> They ruled that their privacy and fairness standards did not apply to deceased individuals – they did point out, however, that TVNZ complied with the judge's stipulations against showing the boy's face and genitals, and, "in this respect, the Authority finds that TVNZ exercised care and discretion in order to preserve the child's dignity."<ref name=bsa/><ref name=DP-complaint-rejected>{{cite news|title=Complaint about autopsy photos rejected|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/archive/national-news/340740/Complaint-about-autopsy-photos-rejected|accessdate=16 October 2012|newspaper=The Dominion Post|date=1 April 2008}}</ref> {{quote box |quote = The more the public of New Zealand is aware of the problem, the more chance something will be done. |source = Roger McClay, Preceding Children's Commissioner, {{nowrap|August 2007}}<ref name="email"/> |width = 25% |align = right |qalign = left |quoted = 1 }} Regarding violence, the Authority quoted from their guidelines, which "recognises that news programmes will often contain 'violent, disturbing or alarming material', and that broadcasters 'should not falsify by omission, a world in which much violence and brutality occurs'".<ref name=bsa>{{cite web |url= http://www.bsa.govt.nz/decisions/show/2971 |title= Kiro and Television New Zealand Ltd - 2007-111; Complaint under section 8(1)(a) of the Broadcasting Act 1989 |work=bsa.govt.nz |date=26 March 2008 |publisher=[[Broadcasting Standards Authority]] |accessdate=5 October 2012}}</ref> That TVNZ provided advance warning to viewers and didn't display the images until two minutes into the story played a role in the BSA's decision-making,<ref name=DP-complaint-rejected/> especially with respect to children's interests. Although the complaints were not upheld, two of the Authority's members went on record to note that "it is unusual to see autopsy photographs in the 6pm news, particularly involving children", and that "the warning could have made a specific reference to autopsy photographs of a child in order to leave viewers in no doubt as to the content of the report."<ref name=bsa/> {{Clear}}
===Email petition=== The images were also circulated in an email sent by a protest group calling for tougher jail terms for child abusers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biggie.co.nz/discussion/the_real_face_of_child_abuse_in_nz_size9warning_tear |title=The real face of child abuse in NZ |work=biggie.co.nz |date=31 July 2007 |accessdate=9 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225155059/http://www.biggie.co.nz/discussion/the_real_face_of_child_abuse_in_nz_size9warning_tear |archivedate=25 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> with Kiro calling their use "abhorrent".<ref name="email-slammed">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/14389/Photos-sent-in-emails-of-dead-boy-slammed |title=Photos sent in emails of dead boy slammed |work=stuff.co.nz |date=5 August 2007|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="grisly">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/46753/Grisly-photos-in-email-petition |title=Grisly photos in email petition |work=stuff.co.nz |date=6 August 2007 |quote=|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> Ngati's name (but not images) were used by [[Family First New Zealand|Family First]] to advocate tougher sentences for child abuse<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0802/S00330.htm |title=Sentence for Beating Partner to Death slammed |publisher=Family First |work=Press Release |date=28 February 2008 |quote=His entire body was covered in bruises and his blood was found in every inch of the house. Yet his mother and step-father will be up for parole in four years. |accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> and to highlight female family violence perpetrators.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0707/S00373.htm |title=Child Abusers Are Also Women |publisher=Family First |work=Press Release|date=31 July 2007 |quote=|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> Family First's Bob McCroskie supported the shock value of the images.<ref name="tvnz 2007" /> The images have also been used on [[protest art|placards]] (protest signs).<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.flickr.com/photos/blake662003/1228828040/ |title=Ngatikaura Ngati |work=flickr.com |year=2011 |accessdate=8 October 2011|quote=}}</ref>
Preceding Commissioner Roger McClay said, that use of the photos would serve to raise awareness of the child abuse "epidemic", which was not well known amongst New Zealanders. He added, "The more the public of New Zealand is aware of the problem, the more chance something will be done."<ref name="email">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/archive/national-news/10681/E-mailer-backs-abuse-photos |publisher=Dominion Post |title=E-mailer backs abuse photos |work=stuff.co.nz |date=6 August 2007 |accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> Inspector Richard Middleton, who was involved in the original police case, said, "The case was very disturbing in view of the amount of violence used against a defenceless three-year-old. Anything that raises awareness and prevents it happening again is great."<ref name="email-slammed"/>
===Shock web sites=== Some time later the photos appeared on Internet [[shock sites]], which some have characterized as [[pornographic websites|pornographic]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dead child's pictures posted on pornographic website|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/national/181383/dead-childs-pictures-posted-pornographic-website|publisher=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=10 October 2012|date=7 October 2011}}</ref> In 2011, months after taking office as [[Children's Commissioner (New Zealand)|Children’s Commissioner]], Russell Wills said he was "appalled" at their use.<ref name="nzherald">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10757456 |title=Disgust over dead boy's pictures on porn site |publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]] |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=8 October 2011 |quote=Ngatikaura Ngati died after horrific abuse by his parents. Children's advocates are appalled that pictures of a young Auckland boy killed by his parents were posted on a pornographic site featuring beheadings, impalement and necrophilia. |accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> Even though shock sites did not create the photos, the images nevertheless fueled a squabble ''between'' two such sites in 2011, wherein one lodged an unsuccessful [[DCMA complaint|DCMA (copyright) complaint]] with [[Google]] against the other.<ref name="chillingeffects">{{cite web |first=Mark |last=Marek|url=https://www.chillingeffects.org/notice.cgi?sID=62669 |title=Articles DMCA (Copyright) Complaint to Google -- Chilling Effects Clearinghouse |work=chillingeffects.org |date=28 April 2011 |quote=Original content: [http://www.bestgore.com/murder/ngatikaura-ngati-story-pictures-child-beaten-death/] Alleged copyright-infringing page: [http://forum.goregrish.com/threads/ngatikaura-ngati-%E2%80%93-story-pictures-of-a-child-beaten-to-death.11706/] |accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref>
== Court documents == * [http://www.nzlii.org/cgi-bin/sinodisp/nz/cases/NZHC/2007/1727.html R v Ngati HC Auckland CRI-2006-092-01919 2007 NZHC 1727 (8 May 2007)] * [http://www.nzlii.org/cgi-bin/sinodisp/nz/cases/NZHC/2007/1850.html R v Ngati HC Auckland CRI-2006-092-001919 2007 NZHC 1850 (15 June 2007) ] * [http://www.nzlii.org/cgi-bin/sinodisp/nz/cases/NZBSA/2008/25.html TVNZ and Kiro - One News - Autopsy photos of child - Good taste and decency, privacy, fairness, programme classification, children's interests, and violence - Not upheld. - 2007-111 2008 NZBSA 25 (26 March 2008) ] * [http://www.nzlii.org/cgi-bin/sinodisp/nz/cases/NZIPT/2011/500158.html Fa'asisila v Minister of Immigration 2011 NZIPT 500158 (9 December 2011)]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ngati, Ngatikaura}} [[Category:Child abuse resulting in death]] [[Category:Crime in New Zealand]] [[Category:Privacy case law]] [[Category:Privacy controversies and disputes]] [[Category:New Zealand people of Tongan descent]] [[Category:Adoptees adopted by relations]] [[Category:Digital Millennium Copyright Act takedown incidents]]

A '''benevolent dictatorship''' refers to a government in which an [[authoritarian]] leader exercises absolute political power over the state but is perceived to do so with regard for benefit of the population as a whole, standing in contrast to the decidedly malevolent stereotype of a [[dictator]]. A benevolent dictator may allow for some [[economic liberalization]] or [[democracy|democratic decision-making]] to exist, such as through public [[referendum|referenda]] or [[elect]]ed [[Representative democracy|representative]]s with limited power, and often makes preparations for a [[Democratization|transition to genuine democracy]] during or after their term. It might be seen as a [[republic]]an form of [[enlightened despotism]]. The label has been applied to leaders such as [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] of [[Turkey]],{{cite web |title=Benevolent Dictator? Thinking About MK Atatürk |url=http://turkeyfile.blogspot.com/2009/10/benevolent-dictator.html |work=Turkey File |date=October 19, 2009}} [[Josip Broz Tito]] of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]],{{cite book |last1=Shapiro |first1=Susan |last2=Shapiro |first2=Ronald |title=The Curtain Rises: Oral Histories of the Fall of Communism in Eastern Europe |publisher=McFarland |year=2004 |isbn=0-7864-1672-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oCqWFQ1WKlkC&pg=PA180 |ref=Shapiro_2004}}
"...All Yugoslavs had educational opportunities, jobs, food, and housing regardless of nationality. Tito, seen by most as a benevolent dictator, brought peaceful co-existence to the Balkan region, a region historically synonymous with factionalism." [[Lee Kuan Yew]] of [[Singapore]],{{Cite news |title=What Singapore can teach us |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/what-singapore-can-teach-us/2012/05/02/gIQAlQEGwT_story.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=2012-05-02|access-date = 2015-11-25 |issn=0190-8286 |first=Matt |last=Miller}} and [[France-Albert René]] of [[Seychelles]]. == Characteristics == The idea of benevolent dictatorship has a long history, dating back to various positively-perceived{{who|date=July 2018}} rulers during ancient times,{{when|date=July 2018}} where authoritarian leadership was the norm.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} Modern usage of the term in a world society where the norm leans much more toward democracy can be traced back to [[John Stuart Mill]] in his classic ''[[On Liberty]]'' (1869). Although he argued in favor of democratic rights for individuals, he did make an exception for what he called today's developing countries:{{Cite web |url=https://williameasterly.files.wordpress.com/2011/05/benevolent-autocrats-easterly-2nd-draft.pdf |title=Benevolent Autocrats |website=}}
We may leave out of consideration those backward states of society in which the race itself may be considered as in its nonage. Despotism is [...] legitimate [...] in dealing with barbarians, provided the end be their improvement [...]. Liberty [...] has no application to any state of things anterior to the time when mankind have become capable of being improved by free and equal discussion.
Benevolent dictator was also a popular rhetoric in the early 20th century as a support for colonial rulings. A British colonial official called Lord Hailey said in 1940s "A new conception of our relationship...may emerge as part of the movement for the betterment of the backward peoples of the world." Hailey conceived economic development as a justification for colonial power. In the Spanish language, the pun word ''[[dictablanda]]'' is sometimes used for a dictatorship conserving some of the liberties and mechanisms of democracy.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} The pun is that, in Spanish, ''dictadura'' is "dictatorship", ''dura'' is "hard" and ''blanda'' is "soft". Analogously, the same pun is made in Portuguese as ''ditabranda'' or ''ditamole''. In February 2009, the Brazilian newspaper ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'' ran an editorial classifying the [[military dictatorship in Brazil]] (1964–1985) as a "ditabranda", creating controversy.{{cite web |url=http://portalimprensa.uol.com.br/colunistas/colunas/2009/02/25/imprensa374.shtml |title=A "ditabranda" da ''Folha'' |publisher=Portal Imprensa |first=Igor |last=Ribeiro |date=February 25, 2009 |language=pt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201152634/http://portalimprensa.uol.com.br/colunistas/colunas/2009/02/25/imprensa374.shtml |archivedate=2012-02-01 |df=}} [[Mancur Olson]] characterized benevolent dictators as "not like the wolf that preys on the elk, but more like the rancher who makes sure his cattle are protected and are given water".{{Cite journal |last=Olson |first=Mancur |date=1993-01-01 |title=Dictatorship, Democracy, and Development |jstor=2938736 |journal=The American Political Science Review |volume=87 |issue=3 |pages=567–576 |doi=10.2307/2938736}} This analogy helps explain the seemingly contradictory motivations for benevolence. What seems altruistic on behalf of the dictator is actually acting in [[rational self interest]]. The provision of public goods allows for a [[Pareto improvement]] in society, from which the dictator can extract taxes to enrich himself or the state. == Modern examples == === Josip Broz Tito === Although [[Josip Broz Tito]] led the former republic of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] as [[Prime Minister of Yugoslavia|Prime Minister]] and [[President of Yugoslavia|President]] (later [[President for Life]]) from 1944 until his death in 1980 under what many criticized as [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] rule,{{cite book |title=Group Psychotherapy and Political Reality: A Two-Way Mirror |last1=Cohen |first1=Bertram D. |last2=Ettin |first2=Mark F. |last3=Fidler |first3=Jay W. |year=2002 |publisher=International Universities Press |isbn=0-8236-2228-2 |page=193}}{{cite book |last=Andjelic |first=Neven |title=Bosnia-Herzegovina: The End of a Legacy |publisher=Frank Cass |year=2003 |page=36 |isbn=0-7146-5485-X}}{{cite book |title=Accommodating National Identity: New Approaches in International and Domestic Law |last=Tierney |first=Stephen |year=2000 |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers |isbn=90-411-1400-9 |page=17}}Naming Street After Tito Unconstitutional. Slovenia Times, 5 October 2011 http://www.sloveniatimes.com/naming-street-after-tito-unconstitutional he was widely popular and was "seen by most as a benevolent dictator". This perception has changed significantly in [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] circles following the [[dissolution of Yugoslavia]] and the examination of various crimes committed by the [[Yugoslav Partisans]] in the aftermath of the World War II and the [[Communist Party of Yugoslavia]] during its rule, namely the [[Bleiburg repatriations]], the [[Foibe massacres]], [[Tezno massacre]], [[Macelj massacre]], [[Kočevski Rog massacre]], [[Barbara Pit massacre]] and the [[communist purges in Serbia in 1944–45]]. === Mustafa Kemal Atatürk === During his leadership of the [[Turkish War of Independence]] from 1919 to 1922 and his presidency from 1923 to 1938, [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] is credited with removing foreign influence from former [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] territory, and is looked fondly upon as the founder of modern Turkey.{{cite web |url=http://thepolicywire.com/lee-kuan-yew-the-curious-legacies-of-benevolent-dictators/ |title=Lee Kuan Yew & The Curious Legacies of "Benevolent Dictators" |date=March 27, 2015 |author=Eric Watson |work=The Policy Wire}} He presided over a [[Atatürk's Reforms|series of reforms]] such as allowing women to vote, agrarian land reform, removal of Islam as the state religion and the establishment of [[Secularism in Turkey|secularism]], and the adoption of a Western-based criminal code.{{cite web |url=http://www.columbia.edu/~sss31/Turkiye/ata/hayati.html |title=Mustafa Kemal Atatürk |work=columbia.edu}} === Lee Kuan Yew === Since its independence in 1959, Singapore has transformed from a relatively underdeveloped and impoverished agrarian society into one of Asia's wealthiest nations, a center of international banking, business and shipping. Singapore has thus been dubbed as one of the [[Four Asian Tigers]]. [[Lee Kuan Yew]] and his administration wielded absolute reign over Singaporean politics until 1990, while his [[People's Action Party]] has remained in power ever since, controlling Singapore as a [[dominant-party state]]. Yew is therefore often called a 'benevolent dictator.'{{cite web |url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/obituary-lee-kuan-yew-the-benevolent-dictator |title=Obituary: Lee Kuan Yew, the benevolent dictator |author=BOO SU-LYN |work=Malay Mail}} As a leader who was in power for thirty-one years from 1959 until 1990,{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/23/lee-kuan-yews-legacy-of-authoritarian-pragmatism-will-serve-singapore-well |title=Lee Kuan Yew leaves a legacy of authoritarian pragmatism |author=Carlton Tan |date=March 23, 2015 |work=The Guardian}} he implemented some laws that were deemed to be autocratic, and attempted to dismantle political opposition. Despite this, he is reportedly often looked upon favorably by [[Singaporeans]] for his transformation of Singapore. Peter Popham of [[The Independent]] called Yew "one of the most successful political pragmatists".{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/lee-kuan-yew-an-entirely-exceptional-leader-who-balanced-authoritarianism-with-pragmatism-10128277.html |title=Lee Kuan Yew: An entirely exceptional leader who balanced authoritarianism with pragmatism |author=Peter Popham |date=March 23, 2015 |work=The Independent}} === France-Albert René === Although [[France-Albert René]] seized power in a coup, his one-party rule in [[Seychelles]] rapdily developed the country since its independence. His administration established various administrative, public institutions and educational institutions, created a universal health care system, and brought the national literacy rate to 90%.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} == See also == {{portalbar|politics}} * [[Absolute monarchy]] * [[Benevolent dictator for life]] (related concept in terms of software) * [[Dictablanda]] * [[Enlightened absolutism]] * [[Meritocracy]] * [[Philosopher king]] * [[Separation of powers]] * [[Soft despotism]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Authoritarian types of rule}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benevolent Dictatorship}} [[Category:Political systems]] [[Category:Oligarchy]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2016}} [[File:POL WAW Budynek GUS.jpg|thumb|260px|Main building of Statistics Poland, [[Warsaw]]]]
'''Statistics Poland''' (formerly known in English as the '''Central Statistical Office''' ({{lang-pl|'''Główny Urząd Statystyczny'''}}, popularly called '''GUS''')) is [[Government of Poland|Poland]]'s chief government [[executive agency]] charged with collecting and publishing statistics related to the country's economy, population, and society, at the national and local levels. The president of Statistics Poland (currently [[Dominik Rozkrut]]) reports directly to the [[Prime Minister of Poland]] and is considered the equivalent of a Polish government minister.
[[File:Ludwik krzywicki 1882.jpg|thumb|left|100px|[[Ludwik Krzywicki]]]]
The agency was established in 1918 by [[Ludwik Krzywicki]], one of the most notable sociologists of his time.
Inactive during [[World War II]], GUS was reorganized in 1945.
The office is divided into several separate branches, each responsible for a different set of data. The branches include the Divisions of Coordination of Statistical Surveys, Analyses and Regional Statistics, Dissemination, National Accounts and Finance, Business Statistics and Registers, Social Statistics, Services Statistics, Agriculture and Environment Statistics, International Cooperation, Budgetary, and Personnel.
Notable GUS publications include ''Rocznik Statystyczny'' (Statistical Yearbook), ''Mały Rocznik Statystyczny'' (Concise Statistical Yearbook), and ''Wiadomości Statystyczne'' (Statistical News).
== Former presidents == {{columns |width=20em |gap=3.25em |col1 = * 1918–1929 Józef Buzek * 1929–1939 Edward Szturm de Sztrem * 1939–1945 vacant * 1945–1949 Stefan Szulc * 1949–1965 Zygmunt Pudowicz * 1965–1972 [[Wincenty Kawalec]] * 1972–1980 Stanisław Kuziński * 1980–1989 Wiesław Sadowski |col2 = * 1989–1991 Franciszek Kubiczek * 1991–1992 Bohdan Wyżnikiewicz * 1992–1995 Józef Oleński * 1995–2006 Tadeusz Toczyński * 2006–2006 Janusz Witkowski (acting) * 2006–2011 Józef Oleński * 2011-2016 Janusz Witkowski * since 2016 Dominik Rozkurt }}
==See also== * [[Census in Poland]]
==External links== * [http://www.stat.gov.pl/en/ GUS]
{{coord|52.2167|N|21.0065|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
{{National statistical services of Europe}} {{Authority control}}
