{{Infobox MP | name = Mir Dostain Khan Domki | honorific-suffix = | office= [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Minister of State for Science and Technology]] | term_start = 10 August 2017 |term_end = 31 May 2018 |primeminister = [[Shahid Khaqan Abbasi]] |president = [[Mamnoon Hussain]] | office1 =Member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] | term_start1 = 1 June 2013 |term_end1 = 31 May 2018 |constituency1 = [[Constituency NA-265|NA-265 (Sibi-cum-Kohlu-cum-Dera Bugti- cum-Harani)]] |nationality = Pakistani | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|3|18}} | birth_place = |party = }}
'''Mir Dostain Khan Domki''' ({{Lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|میر دوستین خان ڈومکی}}}}; born 18 March 1974) is a Pakistani politician who had been a member of the [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] from June 2013 to May 2018. He served as [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Minister of State for Science and Technology]] from August to May 2018 in the cabinet of Prime Minister [[Shahid Khaqan Abbasi]].
==Early life== He was born on 18 March 1974.<ref name="pildat/dob">{{cite web|title=Detail Information|url=http://www.pildat.org/mna/rsDetail.asp?detid=265|accessdate=11 July 2017|date=21 April 2014|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421152521/http://www.pildat.org/mna/rsDetail.asp?detid=265|archivedate=21 April 2014|df=}}</ref>
==Political career==
He ran for the seat of [[National Assembly of Pakistan]] as an independent candidate from [[Constituency NA-265|Constituency NA-265 (Sibi-cum-Kohlu-cum-Dera Bugti-cum-Hernai)]] in [[Pakistani general election, 2008]] but was unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite news|title=As Pakistan goes to polls: Take a peek at some major NA constituencies|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/813877|accessdate=10 August 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=10 May 2013|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305114952/https://www.dawn.com/news/813877|archivedate=5 March 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Balochistan poll scene turns topsy-turvy|url=http://nation.com.pk/elections-2013/06-May-2013/balochistan-poll-scene-turns-topsy-turvy|accessdate=10 August 2017|work=The Nation|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810131553/http://nation.com.pk/elections-2013/06-May-2013/balochistan-poll-scene-turns-topsy-turvy|archivedate=10 August 2017|df=}}</ref> He received 17,411 votes and lost the seat to [[Mir Ahmadan Khan Bugti]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2008 election result|url=https://www.ecp.gov.pk/Documents/General%20Elections%202008/Report,%20General%20Election%202008,%20Vol-II.pdf|publisher=ECP|accessdate=12 May 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105060230/https://ecp.gov.pk/Documents/General%20Elections%202008/Report,%20General%20Election%202008,%20Vol-II.pdf|archivedate=5 January 2018|df=}}</ref>
He was elected to the National Assembly as an independent candidate from Constituency NA-265 (Sibi-cum-Kohlu-cum-Dera Bugti- cum-Harani) in [[Pakistani general election, 2013]].<ref>{{cite news|title=138 MNAs either paid no income tax, or FBR has no such data|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/631317-138-mnas-either-paid-no-income-tax,-or-fbr-has-no-such-data|accessdate=6 March 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203161224/https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/631317-138-mnas-either-paid-no-income-tax,-or-fbr-has-no-such-data|archivedate=3 February 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Baloch MNA meets PM Nawaz|url=http://nation.com.pk/national/10-Jun-2014/mna-mir-dostain-khan-domki-meets-pm-nawaz|accessdate=10 August 2017|work=The Nation|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810131520/http://nation.com.pk/national/10-Jun-2014/mna-mir-dostain-khan-domki-meets-pm-nawaz|archivedate=10 August 2017|df=}}</ref> He received 22,874 votes and defeated Ahmed Jan Khan, a candidate of [[Pashtunkhwa Milli Awami Party]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 election result|url=https://ecp.gov.pk/Documents/General%20Elections%202013%20report/Election%20Report%202013%20Volume-II.pdf|publisher=ECP|accessdate=12 May 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201140612/https://ecp.gov.pk/Documents/General%20Elections%202013%20report/Election%20Report%202013%20Volume-II.pdf|archivedate=1 February 2018|df=}}</ref>
Following the election of [[Shahid Khaqan Abbasi]] as Prime Minister of Pakistan in August 2017, he was inducted into the cabinet of [[Abbasi ministry|Abbasi]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Four new ministers take oath at President House|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1350766/four-new-ministers-take-oath-at-president-house|accessdate=10 August 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=10 August 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810170851/https://www.dawn.com/news/1350766/four-new-ministers-take-oath-at-president-house|archivedate=10 August 2017|df=}}</ref> as [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Minister of State for Science and Technology]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Balochistan to become most developed province soon: PM|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/235203-Balochistan-to-become-most-developed-province-soon-PM|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=www.thenews.com.pk|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Bloated cabinet: Influential ministers with powerless underlings - The Express Tribune|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1515317/bloated-cabinet-influential-ministers-powerless-underlings/|accessdate=26 September 2017|work=The Express Tribune|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> In November 2017, he announced to step down from the ministerial office of Science and Technology after [[Rana Tanveer Hussain]] was appointed as federal minister for Science and Technology.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reporter|first1=A|title=State minister Dostain Domki resigns|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1373282|accessdate=28 November 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=28 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Domki’s bid to eradicate corruption from ministry leads to his resignation|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/11/27/domkis-bid-to-eradicate-corruption-from-ministry-leads-to-his-resignation/|accessdate=28 November 2017|work=www.pakistantoday.com.pk}}</ref> His resignation was not accepted until December 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Abbasi|first1=Kashif|title=Minister orders probe into NTS affairs|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1373774/minister-orders-probe-into-nts-affairs|accessdate=30 November 2017|work=DAWN.COM|date=30 November 2017}}</ref>
In April 2018, he quit PML-N and joined the newly created [[Balochistan Awami Party]] (BAP).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hussain|first1=Javed|title=Magsi, Kamal, Domki quit PML-N, set to join newly-formed BAP|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1399768/magsi-kamal-domki-quit-pml-n-set-to-join-newly-formed-bap|accessdate=5 April 2018|work=DAWN.COM|date=5 April 2018}}</ref> Upon the dissolution of the National Assembly on the expiration of its term on 31 May 2018, Domki ceased to hold the office as Minister of State for Science and Technology.<ref>{{cite web |title=Notification |url=http://www.cabinet.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/fm-mos-noti-01-06-2018.pdf |publisher=Cabinet division |accessdate=1 June 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180601180526/http://www.cabinet.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/fm-mos-noti-01-06-2018.pdf |archivedate=1 June 2018}}</ref>

'''Answer of Miss Earth 2012''': "Good evening ladies and gentlemen, I'm so afraid that's my problem because I didn't understand the question so I will try to say this message : I want to say that we have to protect Mother Earth because you know, how big mother earth and the people is not a privilege it's a duty for us living on this planet…she gave us everything what we need to the life, so let's respect her and she will be respect us, so thank you, thank you so much." – [[Tereza Fajksová]], represented Czech Republic.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} ==Judges== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%;" |- ! No. !! Judge !! Background |- | 1 || Harry Morris || Filipino-Welsh Athlete, [[Welsh Premier League]] member and the Philippine Volcanoes Rugby Team Captain, also holds a Marine Biology degree from the [[University of Essex]] |- | 2 || Lawrence Peña || Resident Manager, Best Western Premier F1 Hotel at [[Fort Bonifacio|The Fort]] – the official residence of Miss Earth 2012 candidates |- | 3 || Mayenne Carmona || Society Columnist, writer, and Book Author-Editor |- | 4 || Nancy Yeoh || Malaysian media maven, founder and CEO of Stylo International Datuk |- | 5 || Bobby Ray Parks Jr. || Filipino-American Athlete, [[UAAP]] MVP basketball player from the National University, son of the basketball legend and [[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] hall-of-famer [[Bobby Ray Parks]] |- | 6 || Eddie Tan || [[Star World]] channel Executive |- | 7 || Allen Roxas || Chairperson and president of Statemotor Corporation and Versailles Palace [[Alabang]] State Properties |- | 8 || Joseph Foltz || United States Agency for International Development ([[USAID]]) deputy chief of the Energy, Environment and Climate Change |- | 9 || [[Edward Hagedorn]] || [[Puerto Princesa City]], [[Palawan]] mayor, a top local official who campaigned the world famous [[Puerto Princesa Subterranean River]] to be included in the [[New7Wonders of Nature]] |} ==Background music== * '''Opening''': "Dance Again Remix" by [[Jennifer Lopez]] * '''Evening Gown Competition''': "Diamonds ([[Rihanna]])" by Jordan Ware (Violin Remix) * '''Swimsuit Competition''': "Fashionista" by [[Jimmy James (singer)|Jimmy James]] (Instrument) ==Controversies== Miss Earth [[Russia]], Natalia Pereverzeva, has been heavily criticized for posing topless and for being the cover girl of the Russian Playboy’s May 2011 issue (about six months before when she was crowned new Miss Earth Russia 2012). The 24 year old model and former finance specialist, then sporting a blonde hair, appeared to have her hands covering her private parts and did a double breast exposure. Pereverzeva kept mum about the topless photos when asked by media. She stated, "I don’t think that’s a good question for [[Miss Earth]]. Real beauty should be not only natural beauty but the beauty should come from the inside". Her fellow candidates have mixed reactions regarding the issue. However, the organizers of the [[Miss Earth]] contest came to the defense of the Russian beauty, saying Pereverzeva did not violate moral standards. They also said Pereverzeva’s Playboy pictorial was not as daring as the [[Playboy]] spread of another European contest who was not allowed to participate in the pageant. "We cannot enforce our own cultural standards on candidates from other countries. Since Miss Earth is a global endeavor, Miss Russia was chosen through a legitimate official process in her country," [[Lorraine Schuck]], Miss Earth executive vice president, said in a statement.http://beta.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/11/12/12/miss-russias-topless-playboy-photos-spark-debate Barely after a week, Miss Russia made the international headlines once again by provoking an outrage in her motherland by calling it "a beggar" and "my poor long-suffering country, mercilessly torn to pieces by greedy, dishonest, unbelieving people".{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/9687920/Russias-Miss-Earth-contestant-in-extraordinary-rant-against-country.html |title=Russia's Miss Earth contestant in extraordinary rant against country |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}} The source of the outrage came from a response to a standard question about what made her proud of her country and what she could promote about it, asked of all contestants of Miss Earth which has been stated in the pageant's official website.{{cite web|url=http://www.missearth.tv/delegates_russia.php |title=MISS RUSSIA : Natalia Pereverzeva |publisher=Missearth.tv |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}} Pereverzeva began by praising her country, saying it was, "a kind cow with very big eyes, funny horns and always chewing its mouth; oh, what sweet milk she gives!"http://www.thegloss.com/2012/11/20/beauty/miss-earth-russia-natalia-pereverzeva-424/http://www.businessinsider.com/natalia-pereverzeva-miss-earth-rant-2012-11http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/what-about-world-peace-miss-earth-hopeful-natalia-pereverzeva-wages-war-on-beggar-russia/story-e6frfmqi-1226520351550 But, veering off message, she added: "My Russia is a beggar. My Russia cannot help her elderly and orphans. From it, bleeding, like from a sinking ship, engineers, doctors, teachers are fleeing, because they have nothing to live on. My Russia – it is an endless Caucasian war."http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-11-20/news/35241322_1_miss-earth-beauty-pageant-contestant The stinging indictment, published in full on the pageant's website, caused a furore in Russia.{{cite web|author=Reuters – Tue, Nov 20, 2012 |url=http://news.yahoo.com/russian-beauty-queen-criticizes-life-under-putin-174911062.html |title=Russian beauty queen criticizes life under Putin - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=2012-11-20 |accessdate=2012-11-25}}http://www.newstrackindia.com/newsdetails/2012/11/20/111-Russia-is-a-beggar-says-Miss-Earth-entrant-Natalia-Pereverzeva.html {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Result ! {{Infobox law enforcement agency | agencyname = National Supervisory Commission of the People's Republic of China | nativenamea = {{lang|zh-Hans|中华人民共和国国家监察委员会}} | nativenamer = Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó Guójiā Jiānchá Wěiyuánhuì | commonname = National Supervision Commission | logo = File:National Emblem of the People's Republic of China (2).svg | logocaption = [[National Emblem of the People's Republic of China]] | formedyear = March 2018 | country = China | national = yes | headquarters = [[Beijing]], [[China]] | minister1name = [[Yang Xiaodu]] | minister1pfo = Director of the National Supervisory Commission | unittype = [[List of anti-corruption agencies|Anti-corruption agency]] | website = [http://www.ccdi.gov.cn CCDI & NSC official website] }} {{Chinese |title = National Supervisory Commission of the People's Republic of China |order = st |s = 中华人民共和国国家监察委员会 |t = 中華人民共和國國家監察委員會 |p = Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó Guójiā Jiānchá Wěiyuánhuì }} {{Politics of China |expanded = Supervision }}
'''National Supervisory Commission of the People's Republic of China'''<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.chinalawtranslate.com/中华人民共和国监察法（草案）/?lang=en |location = China |title = People's Republic of China Supervision Law (draft) |work=China Law Translate |date=6 November 2017 |accessdate=27 January 2018 }}</ref> is the highest [[List of anti-corruption agencies|anti-corruption agency]] of the [[China|People's Republic of China]], at the same administrative ranking as [[Supreme People's Court]] and [[Supreme People's Procuratorate]]. Its operations are merged with the [[Central Commission for Discipline Inspection]] of the [[Communist Party of China]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ccdi.gov.cn/special/zmsjd/zm19da_zm19da/201802/t20180202_163176.html |location=China |title=Why should the National Supervisory Commission merges its operations with the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection of CPC?(为什么中央纪委与国家监察委员会要合署办公？) |work = Website of CCDI & NSC |date=2 Feb 2018 |accessdate=2 April 2018 }}</ref> The National Supervision Commission was formed at the first session of the [[13th National People's Congress]] in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/30/c_136713601.htm |title=China to set up national supervision commission next year |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=2017-10-30 }}</ref> The Commission includes the director, deputy director, and ordinary members and the director is appointed by the [[National People's Congress]].<ref>{{Cite news |url = http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=189250&sid=3 |title = Anti-graft campaign to broaden |work=[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]] |date=2017-11-06 }}</ref>
== Background == The National Supervisory Commission was formed as part of a series of reforms to China's anti-corruption system during the first term of [[Xi Jinping]] as General Secretary of the Communist Party. While the Communist Party had institutionalized internal mechanisms for combating corruption in some form since its early days, it was apparent that it was largely ineffective at curbing systemic corruption, and otherwise had no legal basis, as the main organ tasked with combating corruption and malfeasance, the [[Central Commission for Discipline Inspection]], was a party organ, not a state one.<ref name="dengj">{{cite journal|last1=Deng|first1=Jinting|title=The National Supervision Commission: A New Anti-corruption Model in China|journal=International Journal of Law, Crime and Justice|date=March 2018|volume=52|page=58-73|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1756061617300848}}</ref>
Prior to Xi's anti-corruption campaign, offenses were often prosecuted at the direction of local party authorities through their control of local Commissions for Discipline Inspection (CDIs) and procuratorial organs. While these authorities theoretically reported to their superior commissions at the next higher level of administration (i.e. the municipal organ would report to the provincial one, the provincial organ would report into the CCDI), in addition to answering to the local party leadership, in reality the local CDIs only answered to local party leaders, as they controlled the budgets, personnel, and resources of these organizations. This often led to arbitrary exercise of power and political selectiveness in the targets of corruption efforts.<ref name="dengj"/>
==Formation== In late 2016, Supervisory Commissions (SCs) began pilot initiatives in [[Shanxi]], [[Beijing]] and [[Zhejiang]]. Provincial level chiefs of Discipline Inspection began serving concurrently as heads of the local Supervisory Commissions.<ref name="dengj"/>
The formation of the National Supervisory Commission centralized control of anti-corruption resources to the central authorities and was aimed at curbing local interference in anti-corruption efforts. The former National Anti-Corruption Bureau, the Office Against Dereliction of Duty, and the anti-corruption department of the Procuratorate were all folded into a single agency.<ref name="dengj" />
In February 2018, an amendment to the [[Constitution of the People's Republic of China|constitution]] was proposed to make national and local supervision commissions official state organs. Local commissions will be appointed by local peoples' congresses at county and higher level and will be accountable to them and to the supervision commission at the higher level.<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/25/c_136999323.htm |title=CPC proposes listing supervisory commissions as state organs in Constitution|last=|first=|date=2018-02-25|website=www.xinhuanet.com|publisher=Xinhua|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping]] * [[Censorate]] (imperial China) * [[Central Leading Group for Inspection Work]] * [[Commission Against Corruption (Macau)]] * [[Control Yuan]] (Republic of China) * [[Corruption in China]] * [[Independent Commission Against Corruption (Hong Kong)]] * [[Ministry of Supervision]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Use Pakistani English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Pakistanis in Bahrain |image = |caption = |population = 50,000,<ref name="pak_bah">[http://www.dawn.com/2011/03/22/pakistan-workers-seek-escape-after-bahrain-attacks.html Pakistani workers seek escape after Bahrain attacks, Dawn News, 22 Mar 2011]</ref> 65,000,<ref>[http://www.pakistantimes.net/pt/detail.php?newsId=19856 Bahrain ensures security to Pakistanis: FO Spokesperson, Pakistan Times, retrieved 22 Mar 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314122118/http://www.pakistantimes.net/pt/detail.php?newsId=19856 |date=14 March 2012 }}</ref> 80,166,<ref>[http://dawn.com/2013/03/30/overseas-pakistanis-vote-ecp-nadra-for-caution/ Iftikhar A. Khan, Overseas Pakistanis’ vote: ECP, Nadra for caution, Dawn, 30 March 2013.]</ref> including 10,000<ref name="stat">[http://www.dawn.com/2011/03/30/bahrain-agrees-to-augment-defence-ties-with-pakistan.html Bahrain agrees to augment defence ties with Pakistan, By Baqir Sajjad Syed, 30 Mar 2011, Dawn]</ref> serving in security forces. |popplace = [[Manama]] |langs = [[Urdu]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Gulf Arabic]], [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] |rels = [[Sunni Islam]] and [[Christianity]] |related = [[Indians in Bahrain]] }}
'''Pakistanis in Bahrain''' comprise [[Pakistani people]] living as expatriates or immigrants in [[Bahrain]] and their locally born descendants. The Overseas Pakistanis Foundation estimates that the population of Pakistanis in Bahrain is between 50,000 and 60,000. The Pakistani community maintains two schools, the Pakistan School, Bahrain (managed by parents elected board, Patron in chief- Ambassador of Islamic Republic of Pakistan) and [[Pakistan Urdu School, Bahrain|Pakistan Urdu School]] (private school under Asgharali perfume company) which educates community youth.
For the welfare of the Pakistani community in Bahrain, the Pakistan Club has been established in [[Manama]], which holds numerous events such as Iftar Nights and National Day celebrations.<ref name="Pakistan Club celebrates National Day">[http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?srch=1&storyid=203038], Pakistan Club Celebrates National Day.</ref><ref name="Pakistan Club iftar for Women">[http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?srch=1&storyid=227885], Pakistan Club Iftar for Women.</ref>
==Profession and integration==
Pakistanis have been in Bahrain since 1920. The first group to arrive to Bahrain were the people who came with the army of Al-Khalifa who were majority Balochs. The British Army also sent its most reliable force from Punjab and India to Bahrain. The presence of Pakistanis in Bahrain dates back to 1950. Bahrain is the first Arab country to grant citizenship to people who had served its country. A Pakistani can be granted citizenship after working for the government for 25 years. Up to 30,000 Pakistanis are thought to have obtained Bahraini citizenship.<ref>http://www.abna24.com/english/service/bahrain/archive/2014/12/17/658827/story.html</ref>
==Service in Bahrain== Majority of Pakistanis work in public protection and the army to help provide security for Bahrain. The young educated people tend to put there effort in helping Bahrain's economy, which has been hit severely by the ongoing protests.<ref>http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/05/07/148147.html</ref> The protests have seen many Pakistanis injured by mobs.<ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/127573/several-hurt-as-sunnis-shiites-clash-in-bahrain/ ET]</ref> Up to two Pakistani policemen and two Pakistani civilians have been killed by angry Shia protesters.<ref name="pak_bah2">[http://www.dawn.com/2011/03/22/pakistanis-in-bahrain.html Pakistanis in Bahrain, From the Editorial, ''Dawns Newspaper'', 22 Mar 2011]</ref>
The Pakistan army affiliated [[Fauji Foundation]] and Pakistan navy affiliated Bahria Foundation<ref name="pak_bah2"/> have also been recruiting Pakistani military personnel as for the Bahrain National Guard (a paramilitary body). Following the [[2011 Bahraini protests]], advertisements for additional 800<ref>[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/144961/bahrain-national-guard-recruit-former.html Bahrain National Guard to recruit former soldiers from Pak, Deccan Herald, Islamabad, 11 March 2011]</ref>-1,000<ref>[http://www.dawn.com/2011/03/24/bahrain-spillover-to-spread-to-pakistan.html Bahrain spillover to spread to Pakistan? By Cyril Almeida, 24 Mar 2011, Dawn News]</ref> recruits had been advertised in Pakistani newspapers. This is in addition to at least (conservative estimate) 2,000 Pakistanis already serving in Bahrain security forces (military and police force).<ref>[http://tribune.com.pk/story/131455/ex-servicemen-export-mercenaries-to-the-middle-east/ Ex-servicemen ‘export’ mercenaries to the Middle East, By [[Saba Imtiaz]], Published: 12 March 2011, ''Express Tribune'']</ref> According to an estimate by the ''Wall Street Journal'', Pakistanis contribute at least up to 7,000 of the 25,000 strong Bahrain police force.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703784004576220762563363574 Bahrain's Foreign Police Add to Tensions, by ALEX DELMAR-MORGAN and TOM WRIGHT, MARCH 25, 2011]</ref> In total, almost 10,000 Pakistanis contribute to various Bahrain security forces.<ref name="stat"/> The Pakistan army and Bahrain National Guard are also known to maintain strong ties.<ref>[http://www.ispr.gov.pk/front/main.asp?o=t-press_release&id=317 ISPR Press release, No PR27/2008-ISPR, Dated: 2 May 2008]</ref>
==Military presence== Pakistan maintains a two battalion strong military base in Bahrain, comprising some 1300 men and an armour squadron.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
==Education== [[Pakistan Urdu School]] educates Pakistanis in Bahrain.
==Notable people== * Zeeshan Jawed Shah - Filmmaker<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iris.nyit.edu/~zshah01|title=Home|website=iris.nyit.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> * Fatima Albalooshi – Minister of Health {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} * [[Salah Abdul Rasool Al Blooshi]] – former Guantanamo prisoner {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} * [[Adil Hanif]] – athlete * [[Mohammed Khalid]] – former [[Member of Parliament|MP]] {{citation needed|date=September 2014}} * Mohammad Sajid – Executive Board Member of the Bahrain Chamber of Commerce & Industry; businessman
==See also== {{Portal|Bahrain|Pakistan}} *[[Bahrain–Pakistan relations]] *[[Embassy of Pakistan, Manama]]
==External links== *[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-196266192.html Pakistanis mark National Day in Bahrain] *[http://www.springerlink.com/content/vl680583233g5514/ Anthropometric Characteristics of Pakistani School Children Living in Bahrain] *[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2006%5C04%5C26%5Cstory_26-4-2006_pg7_18 Squatters occupying overseas Pakistanis’ homes in Bahrain: ambassador] * [http://www.smc.org.ph/amnews/amn070815/middleast/bahrain070815.htm Bahrain Immigration]

revision.text:
'''Prostopinije''' (meaning Plain Chant in [[Rusin language|Rusyn]]) is a type of [[monody|monodic]] church [[chant]], closely related to [[Znamenny Chant]]. Prostopinije is used in the [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church]], [[Slovak Greek Catholic Church]] and among the [[ACROD|Carpatho-Russian Orthodox]].
The tradition of Prostopinije chant is used in the lands of [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]], [[Volhyn]] and [[Ruthenia]].<ref name=drill>[http://www.patronagechurch.com/HTML/full_congregational_participatio.htm David Drillock. "LITURGICAL SONG IN THE WORSHIP OF THE CHURCH"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221115557/http://www.patronagechurch.com/HTML/full_congregational_participatio.htm |date=2011-02-21 }} in ISSN 0036-3227 VOLUME 41 NUMBERS 2-3, 1997 ST. VLADIMIR’S THEOLOGICAL QUARTERLY pages 204-205]</ref> The Prostopinije traces its roots to the [[Slavs|Slavic]] traditions of [[Old Kievan chant]] and [[Bulgarian chant]], both stemming from the ancient [[Byzantine chant]] tradition; however, it was also affected by the local folk [[Carpathian music]].<ref name=a>[http://www.patronagechurch.com/HTML/Prostopinije.23.HTM Article about Prostopinije] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812054134/http://www.patronagechurch.com/HTML/Prostopinije.23.HTM |date=2011-08-12 }} at patronagechurch.com. Published in the Byzantine Leaflet Series No. 23, November 1981, Byzantine Seminary Press, Pittsburgh, PA 15214</ref> The Prostopinije chant is purely [[monody|monodic]], lacking [[ison (music)|ison]] or any other support, as well as folk choral [[polyphony]].<ref name=a/> Melodically, Prostopinije resembles [[Znamenny Chant]], and is closely related to it historically,<ref name=mci>[http://www.metropolitancantorinstitute.org/prostopinije/Prostopinije.html Prostopinije] at the page of Metropolitan Cantor Institute (www.metropolitancantorinstitute.org)</ref> but is considerably richer with [[chromatic]] movements, reflecting its relative closeness to the [[Bulgarian people|Bulgarian]] branch of the [[Byzantine chant|Byzantine]] tradition.
==History== By the end of the 18th century, the first attempt to systematize and write down the body of Prostopinije melodies was undertaken by the cantor [[John Juhasevich]] (1741–1814). In 1793, a ''Preparatory School for Cantors and Teachers'' was established in [[Uzhorod]] by Bishop [[Andrew Bachinskyj]].<ref name=a/>
In the 19th century and earlier, in liturgical practice, the chanting was performed by the trained [[Hazzan|cantor]] soloist; however, by the end of the 19th century, through the efforts of Father [[Andrew Popovich]] (1809–1898,[[Velika Kopanya]], [[Ugocha]] district), the tradition was changed drastically,<ref name=a/> and the whole congregation present in the church started to participate in the singing. This strong participation of lay people in the church singing was and still remains a relatively unique phenomenon among the similar chanting traditions.<ref name=drill/>
In the beginning of the 20th century, some efforts to unify the Subcarpathian chanting traditions were also undertaken under supervision of Bishop [[Julius Firczak]] of [[Mukačevo]] by father [[John Bokšai]] (or Bokshai, 1874–1940) and cantor [[Joseph Malinič]], resulting in a publication of first manual<ref name=bokshai>[http://www.metropolitancantorinstitute.org/books/Bokshai/index.html The Cerkovnoje Prostopinije (Church Plainchant) of Father John Bokšai and Cantor Joseph Malinič]</ref> for the Carpathian Plain Chant,<ref name=a/> which was published in [[Užhorod]] in 1906.<ref name=bokshai/>
In many Orthodox parishes both in [[Eastern Europe]] and in the United States, the Prostopinije tradition was replaced by the [[polyphonic]] [[Russian Orthodox Church]] style of singing. Following the union of some of the [[Rusyns|Rusin]] parishes with the [[Orthodox Church in America]], inspired by father [[Alexis Toth]], the Prostopinije was discriminated against, and was in some cases replaced by the [[Obikhod]]. A gradual return to this traditional singing is happening now, however, quite similar to processes of re-introduction of ancient chants in other churches and denominations.<ref>[http://www.byzcath.org/forums/ubbthreads.php/topics/191467/Prostopinije Discussion on Prostopinije] at the Byzantine Forum at byzcath.org</ref>
==Notation== Unlike with some other chanting traditions, Prostopinije remained a primarily aural, unwritten tradition for the major part of its history.<ref name=mci/> There were ongoing attempts to notate this chant, however, primarily as a means to systematize and unify it: first in [[Znamenny chant]] [[neumes]], then (as of about year 1600) in "square and diamond" notation.<ref>[http://puluka.com/home/LiturgicalChant/Prostopinije/ProstopinijeHistory.html History of] Prostopinije at puluka.com</ref> Neither of these systems became really widespread, however.<ref name=a/> In the contemporary practice the chant is written in standard Western staff notation.<ref name=scores>[http://www.patronagechurch.com/chant/chant_table.htm Scores to download] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716140604/http://patronagechurch.com/chant/chant_table.htm |date=2011-07-16 }} patronagechurch.com</ref>
==Local Variations== Due to the predominantly oral nature of the Prostopinije tradition, the majority of melodies do exist in various local variants, sometimes being different even in villages located nearby. Two biggest branches of the tradition may be named, however: those originating from the [[cathedral]] towns of [[Mukačevo]] and [[Prešov]]. Due to the geography of the region, the former of these 2 traditions become the main tradition of the [[Byzantine Rite Catholic Church]]es (through the [[Byzantine Catholic Archeparchy of Pittsburgh]]), while the latter is relatively more used in the [[American Carpatho-Russian Orthodox Diocese]].<ref>[http://www.metropolitancantorinstitute.org/prostopinije/Melodies.html Prostopinije Melodies] at the metropolitancantorinstitute.org</ref>
The Prostopinije chant was traditionally performed either in [[Church Slavonic]], or in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] (with the Hungarian-language parishes adhering musically to the tradition of [[Mukačevo]]).<ref name=bokshai/> In the modern practice in the United States this chant is performed in English as well.<ref name=scores/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links and further reading== * [http://mci.archpitt.org Metropolitan Cantor Institute] - Archeparchy of Pittsburgh library of chant recordings and sheet music. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110716140604/http://patronagechurch.com/chant/chant_table.htm Prostopinije] - a page dedicated to the tradition, with a library of scores (in a Western staff notation), and sound examples. * [http://puluka.com/home/index.php?id=56 The Standard Teaching Text for Rusyn Chant] By Steve Puluka
{{Chant}}
[[Category:Christian chants]] [[Category:Ukrainian music]] [[Category:Rusyn culture]]

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} University '''Rag''' societies are student-run charitable fundraising organisations that are widespread in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Most universities in the UK and Ireland, as well as some in South Africa and the [[Netherlands]] have a Rag. In some universities Rags are known as Charities Campaigns, Charity Appeals, Charity Committees, or Karnivals, but they all share many attributes.
In the UK, the '''National Student Fundraising Association (NaSFA)''', set up in December 2011, exists as a support and resource sharing organisation run by those managing rags for others managing RAGs.
==Origins== [[File:University of Pretoria RAG.jpg|thumb|right|200px| <center> [[University of Pretoria]] welcoming of first years in Pretoria's Church Square in 1910 </center>]]
The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' states that the origin of the word "Rag" is from "An act of ragging; esp. an extensive display of noisy disorderly conduct, carried on in defiance of authority or discipline", and provides a citation from 1864, noting that the word was known in Oxford before this date.<ref>Oxford English Dictionary, ''rag'', University slang</ref> Early Rag collectors may have ''ragged'' passers-by until they made a donation.
Alternatively, it is thought to be{{By whom|date=November 2013}} from the [[Victorian era]] when students took time out of their studies to collect rags to clothe the poor.
Much more recently, [[backronym]]s have been invented for ''RAG'' to stand for "Raise and Give", "Raise A Grand" or "Raising and Giving"; these were, purportedly, coined to convince a manager in a large charity of the value of working with student fundraisers.
The first Rag in South Africa was started at the [[University of Pretoria]] in 1925.<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-174603121.html Retrieved April 1, 2010]{{dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref> The students took to the streets in parade that still exists today and is known as the Procession. During this parade, where they build [[Float (parade)|floats]], they carry cans and ask the spectating public to make donations. Today RAGs held at [[Afrikaans]] universities is called JOOL. The acronym (Jou Onbaatsugtige Opoffering vir Liefdadigheid) is translated from Afrikaans as "Your selfless sacrifice for charity". The annual JOOL/RAG week is held at the start of every academic year and serves also as a kind of welcoming party to students of the university.
==Fundraising==
===Rag Week=== [[File:MidKent College Rag Day 1951.jpg|thumb|200px|<center>Students take part in the [[MidKent College|Medway Technical College]] annual Rag Day parade (1951)</center>]] Traditionally fundraising activities have centred on an annual '''Rag Week''', with events each day for the week. While some Rags are only active for this week, others use "Rag Week" as their flagship week to encourage participation for the whole year.
===Rag Mag=== A ''''Rag mag'''' is a small booklet traditionally filled with [[politically incorrect]] humour which was originally sold to the local community during Rag Week. Some university Rags with a strong local tradition still sell their Rag Mags, however the majority of others use theirs more as information-tools for new students wanting to know more about Rag.
A number of Rags claim to have published the first ever Rag mags:
Sheffield University Rag's [[Twikker]] was first produced in 1925.{{fact|date=May 2017}} Manchester University published a Rag mag in 1924.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archiveshub.jisc.ac.uk/data/gb133-sua|title=Archive of the University of Manchester Students Union - Archives Hub|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> An issue of a Rag mag dating from 1923, called "Goblio", is in the archives of the University of Southampton.{{fact|date=May 2017}} However, Queen's University Belfast holds the most complete set of Rag magazines in its archives, holding 81 different copies of PTQ (''Pro Tanto Quid'' – taken from the city's motto "[[Belfast#Coat of arms and motto|Pro tanto quid retribuamus]]") from 1927 onwards.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
===Sponsored challenges and fundraising events===
Many Rags raise the majority of their money for charity through sponsored challenges and fundraising events. While these vary from University to University, typical examples of each include:
====Sponsored challenges==== * "Jailbreaks," competitions to get as far from the start and back again within a set period of time, without spending any money on transport. * Sponsored [[skydive]]s * Running events including [[marathon]]s, half marathons and 'Tough Guy' challenges * Climbing expeditions * Sponsored hitch-hikes * other sponsored game of sports
[[Image:UCL-KCL Varsity Rugby 2014.jpg|thumb|[[King's College London]] and [[University College London]], the founding and rival colleges of the [[University of London]], hold their annual varsity rugby rag]]
====Fundraising events==== * [[Pub crawl]]s * [[International Men's Day]] parties * [[World record]] attempts * Bed-runs racing teams with hospital beds. * Pub Quizzes * [[Duck race]]s
Manchester RAG also run one of the longest running sponsored events in the North West, known as [[The Bogle Stroll]], which celebrated its semicentennial anniversary in 2011.
Exeter RAG hold the Biggest World AIDS Day event in the UK, called the Safer Sex Ball, Seeing Thousands of students attending to raise money for Charity, £20,000 of which is annually set aside for local AIDS charity the Eddistone Trust.
===Rag Raids===
'''Street Collections:''' Currently known as 'Raids', volunteer collectors go out into the streets (often in costume) to collect for a specific charity on any given day with buckets rather than the clipboards.
Many Rags also organise week-long 'Tours' over the university holidays in which they will travel from town to town, collecting in each one, and raising thousands of pounds for the beneficiary charity.
'''Megaraids:''' A Megaraid is defined as a Raid where more than one Rag is present and in recent years these have been organised on a massive scale by charities with some events taking place consistently for over a decade. Charities which have a developed student fundraising events include [[Barnardo's]], [[Cancer Research UK]], [[Help the Aged]], [[Hope for Children (HOPE)|Hope for Children]], [[Kidscan]], [[Meningitis UK]], [[Meningitis Research Foundation]], [[Meningitis Trust]] and [[Worldwide Cancer Research (WWCR)|Worldwide Cancer Research]]. All Megaraids tend to include a social aspect and often attract former students who still take part.
==National Student Fundraising Association (NaSFA)== '''NaSFA''' is an association of UK student fundraising organisations. It stands for National Student Fundraising Association and was born out of a meeting of 15 heads of UK RAG organisations at the national Rag conference in Durham 2011. These presidents identified a real potential for dramatic increases in efficiency by sharing knowledge and resources. They lay down some fundamental principles, realised a need for a constant and impartial 3rd party facilitator and duly chose the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|NUS]] from a selection of applications to support the project.
The underlying aims of '''NaSFA''', to foster sharing of resources, knowledge and support for and between student fundraising organisations have contributed to the 30 Rags involved. In December 2011 the original '''NaSFA''' founders invited interested parties to an open meeting at the [[Union of Brunel Students]], to ask for approval on what they had been working on and to give Ed Marsh, the Vice-President of the NUS, a mandate to drive NUS support forwards through the organisation's structure.
==Rag Conference (UK)== An annual conference for RAG societies and Charities is held in the UK. The conference is an opportunity for RAGs, student fundraising organisations, charities and associated partners to come together to network, learn and socialise over three action-packed days. In 2012 the RAG conference was held at Loughborough University, and in 2013, the RAG conference was hosted by The University of Birmingham from the 2 to 5 September. In 2014, the conference was held at the University of York from 26–28 August.
==External links== *[http://www.britishpathe.com/video/london-students-rag/query/newsreels London students in traditional Rag 1940–49]
==See also== *[[Shinerama]] – An annual and traditional cross-Canadian university fundraising campaign functioning similarly to the UK's Rag Week tradition in the Canadian context.
==References== {{reflist}}

A '''Russian Census''' is a [[census]] of the population of [[Russia]]. Such a census has occurred at various irregular points in the history of Russia both before and after its period of incorporation into the [[Soviet Union]]. The first and only complete population census conducted in the period of the [[Russian Empire]] was the [[Russian Empire Census]] conducted in 1897. Another [[Russian Census (1920)|Russian Census occurred in 1920]]. Following the [[breakup of the Soviet Union]], a [[Russian Census (2002)|Russian Census occurred in 2002]], the first population census conducted in the post-Soviet Russia. The next Russian Census thereafter was [[Russian Census (2010)|carried out in 2010]].
==See also== *[[Demographics of Russia]] *[[Soviet Census]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Sanwal Esakhelvi | image = | caption = | birth_name = Sanwal Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Mianwali]], [[Pakistan]] | alma_mater = [[City, University of London]] | residence = London, United Kingdom | occupation = {{flat list| * Singer * songwriter * record producer * [[visual effects supervisor]] * [[sound design]]er }} | parents = [[Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi]]
Bazigha Atta | family = [[Laraib Atta]]
Bilawal Atta | years_active = 2010-present | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = {{flat list| * Vocals * guitar * piano * harmonium }} | Genre = {{flat list| * [[Saraiki music|Saraiki]] * [[Punjabi Music|Punjabi]] * [[electronic music]] }} | associated_acts = [[Coke Studio (Pakistan)|Coke Studio]], [[Strings (band)|Strings]], [[Zohaib Kazi]], [[Hamza Ali]] }} }} '''Sanwal "Atta" Esakhelvi''' is a British-Pakistani [[visual effects supervisor]], [[sound design]]er, singer, musician and songwriter. Before establishing himself as a singer, Esakhelvi was a professional cricketer until 2006 and has worked in British film industry as a VFX artist and sound engineer. He released his first album ''Teray Khayal Mein'' (2017) and debuted as a featured artist in the [[Coke Studio Pakistan (season 10)|tenth-season]] of ''[[Coke Studio Pakistan|Coke Studio]]'' alongside with his father.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1366755|title=The Icon Interview: The Soul of Sanwal|last=Khan|first=Mariam Saeed|date=2017-10-29|work=DAWN.COM|access-date=2018-08-12|language=en-US}} ==Personal life== Esakhelvi was born to veteran Saraiki singer [[Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi]],{{cite web|url= https://tribune.com.pk/story/1079734/attaullah-khan-esakhelvi-on-what-makes-him-the-common-mans-artist/|title=Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi on what makes him the common man’s artist - The Express Tribune|date=6 April 2016|work=The Express Tribune}} and has one sister [[Laraib Atta]] who is also a professional [[VFX]] artist and has worked for several [[Academy Award|Oscar]] winning Hollywood films.{{cite news|title=I hope to work on projects in Pakistan, says Hollywood VFX artist Laraib Atta|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1204684/i-hope-to-work-on-projects-in-pakistan-says-hollywood-vfx-artist-laraib-atta|accessdate=5 September 2015|work=[[DAWN.com]]}}{{cite news|title=Pakistani visual effects prodigy making waves in Hollywood|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/947985/meet-laraib-atta-pakistani-visual-effects-prodigy-in-hollywood/|accessdate=5 September 2015|work=[[The Express Tribune]]}} He also has one brother, Bilawal, who is an actor and director based in [[London]],Spotlight (23 April 2018), [https://www.hum.tv/i-feel-the-pressure-every-time-i-look-at-the-keyboard-or-the-harmonium-sanwal-esakhelvi/ "I feel the pressure every time I look at the keyboard or the harmonium: Sanwal Esakhelvi"], ''HumTV''. Retrieved 17 November 2018. as well as also being a musician.[https://www.starnow.co.uk/bilawalatta Bilawal Atta's profile on ''Star Now''] Esakhelvi graduaed from [[City, University of London]] in [[sound engineering]] when an injury made him quit his professional cricket career, "I was always into sports but then an injury forced music to take over."{{Cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1095784/i-didnt-get-into-music-because-i-had-to-sanwal-esakhelvi/|title=I didn’t get into music because I had to: Sanwal Esakhelvi |first=Mehek|last=Saeed |date=May 2, 2016|work=The Express Tribune|access-date=August 12, 2018|language=en-US}} ==Discography== ===Album=== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Album |- |2016 |''Teray Khayal Mein'' |} ===Television=== ====Soundtracks==== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Title ! Song ! Lyics ! Music ! Co-singer(s) |- |2017 | ''[[Ishq Tamasha]]'' - OST | ''[[Ishq Tamasha]]'' | | | [[Sanam Marvi]] |} ===''Coke Studio'' Pakistan=== {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Season ! Song ! Lyics ! Music ! Co-singer(s) |- |rowspan="2"|2017 |rowspan="2"|[[Coke Studio Pakistan (season 10)|10]] |[[Qaumi Taranah]] |[[Hafeez Jullundhri]] |rowspan="2"|[[Strings (band)|Strings]] |Season's ft. artists |- |Sab Maya Hai ||[[Strings (band)|Strings]] |[[Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi]] |- |rowspan="2"|2018 |rowspan="2"|[[Coke Studio Pakistan (season 11)|11]] |[[Hum Dekhenge]] |[[Faiz Ahmed Faiz]] |[[Ali Hamza]], [[Zohaib Kazi]] |Season's ft. artists |- | Allah Karesi | | |[[Attaullah Khan Esakhelvi]] |} ==References== {{reflist|20}} ==External links== * {{Twitter|msanwala|Sanwal Esakhelvi}} * [http://www.cokestudio.com.pk/season11/sanwal-esakhelvi.html Sanwal Esakhelvi] at ''[[Coke Studio (Pakistan)|Coke Studio]]'' {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Esakhelvi, Sanwal}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Pakistani folk singers]] [[Category:Pakistani male singers]] [[Category:Punjabi people]] [[Category:People from Mianwali District]] [[Category:Punjabi singers]] [[Category:Visual effects artists]] [[Category:Sound designers]] [[Category:Pashtun people]]

'''Services for mental disorders''' offer [[treatment of mental disorders|treatments]], [[support group|support]] or [[advocacy]] to people judged to have [[mental disorders]] (mental illnesses).
==Medical services== [[Family practice]] ([[general practice]]) centers in communities are commonly the first line for assessment of mental health conditions, and may prescribe [[psychiatric drugs]] and sometimes provide basic [[counseling]] or [[therapy]] for "common mental disorders". Secondary medical services may include [[psychiatric hospitals]], although since [[deinstitutionalization]] these have been restricted in favor of [[hospital#Departments|wards]] within general [[hospitals]], and [[community mental health services]] based more locally.
Such services may be provided on an [[inpatient]] or, more commonly, [[outpatient]] basis. They may offer a range of treatments, usually centered around psychiatric drugs, and be provided by a range of [[mental health professionals]], notably [[psychiatrists]] and [[psychiatric and mental health nursing|psychiatric and mental health nurses]]. Non-medical professionals may also be involved, such as [[clinical psychologists]], [[social workers]] and various kinds of [[therapists]] or [[Licensed Professional Counselor|counselors]]. Usually headed by psychiatrists and therefore based on a medical model, multidisiplinary teams may be involved in [[assertive community treatment]] and [[early intervention in psychosis|early intervention]], and may be coordinated via a [[case management (mental health)|case management]] system (sometimes referred to as "service coordination").
==Individual therapy services== Numerous services exist exclusively for the therapy of mental disorders and distress. They may offer [[integrative psychotherapy]] (an eclectic tailored mix of approaches) or a particular approach, such as [[cognitive behavioral therapy]].
==Social care services== Community services often include [[supported housing]] with full or partial supervision, including [[halfway house]]s. Social workers and [[support workers]] provide support and advocacy.
==Consumer, survivor and ex-patient services== Many [[Psychiatric survivors movement|Consumer/survivor/ex-patient]] organizations provide services for those [[labeling theory|labeled]] as having a mental disorder. A number of charities providing services are "consumer-led". There are [[self-help groups for mental health|self-help/mutual support groups]] and day centers or [[Clubhouse Model of Psychosocial Rehabilitation|clubhouses]].<ref>McLean, A. (2003). [http://www.psychosocial.com/IJPR_8/Recovering1-McLean.html Recovering Consumers and a Broken Mental Health System in the United States: Ongoing Challenges for Consumers/ Survivors and the New Freedom Commission on Mental Health. Part I: Legitimization of the Consumer Movement and Obstacles to It.] International Journal of Psychosocial Rehabilitation. 8, 47-57</ref><ref>McLean, A. (2003) [http://www.psychosocial.com/IJPR_8/Recovering1-McLean.html Recovering Consumers and a Broken Mental Health System in the United States: Ongoing Challenges for Consumers/ Survivors and the New Freedom Commission on Mental Health. Part II: Impact of Managed Care and Continuing Challenges] International Journal of Psychosocial Rehabilitation. 8, 58-70.</ref> Staff with a lived experience are now being employed as [[peer support specialist]]s within mental health teams.
==Traditional healing centers== [[Traditional healer|Traditional healing centers]] provide a popular and accessible service across the African continent and other areas of the world, and often deal with mental disorders.<ref>Ngoma MC, Prince M, Mann A (2003) [http://bjp.rcpsych.org/cgi/content/abstract/183/4/349 Common mental disorders among those attending primary health clinics and traditional healers in urban Tanzania.] Br J Psychiatry. 2003 Oct;183:349-55.</ref><ref>Center for Advocacy in Mental Health [http://www.camhindia.org/hhwm_project.html Role of Traditional Healing Centers (THCs) in Mental Health Service Delivery]</ref>
==Legal services== Legal services exist to regulate and supervise the [[involuntary commitment]] or [[outpatient commitment]] of those judged to have mental disorders and to be a danger to themselves or others. Some legal organizations provide specialized services for those diagnosed with mental disorders who may be challenging [[discrimination]] or involuntary commitment. [[Mental health courts]] are specialized court dockets that exist in some places to provide community treatment and supervision in lieu of incarceration for criminal offenders with mental illness.
==Global situation== A Global Mental Health Group in coordination with the [[World Health Organization]] has called for an urgent scaling up of the funding, staffing and coverage of services for mental disorders in all countries, especially in low-income and middle-income countries.<ref>Lancet Global Mental Health Group, Chisholm D, Flisher AJ, Lund C, Patel V, Saxena S, Thornicroft G, Tomlinson M. (2007) [http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140673607612422 Scale up services for mental disorders: a call for action] Lancet. Oct 6;370(9594):1241-52.</ref><ref>World Health Organization [http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2007/pr45/en/index.html WHO urges more investments, services for mental health] WHO website, September 2007</ref>
According to the [[Recovery model]], services must always support an individual's personal journey of recovery and independence, and a person may or may not need services at any particular time, or at all.
The UK is moving towards paying mental health providers by the outcome results that their services achieve.<ref>https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/mental-health-payment-by-results-arrangements-for-2013-14</ref><ref>http://www.communitycare.co.uk/articles/16/04/2013/119098/a-quick-guide-to-mental-health-payment-by-results-and-its-impact-on-social-work.htm</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{nowrap|{{IPA-all|tʰai˧˧ ban˥˧ kʰa˥˥ su˥˥|Zhao'an:}}}} |states=[[Taiwan]] |region=[[Taoyuan County|Taoyuan]], [[Miaoli County|Miaoli]], [[Hsinchu County|Hsinchu]], [[Pingtung County|Pingtung]], [[Kaohsiung]], [[Taichung]], [[Nantou County|Nantou]], [[Changhua County|Changhua]], [[Yunlin County|Yunlin]], [[Yilan County, Taiwan|Yilan]], [[Hualien County|Hualien]] and [[Taitung County|Taitung]] |speakers=2,370,000 |date=1993 |ref={{cite book|editor1-last=Simons|editor1-first=Gary F.|editor2-last=Fennig|editor2-first=Charles D.|title=Ethnologue: Languages of the World|date=2017|publisher=SIL International|location=Dallas, Texas|edition=20th|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/hak|accessdate=1 June 2017|chapter=Chinese, Hakka}} |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam2=[[Varieties of Chinese|Chinese]] |fam3=[[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]] |fam4=[[:zh:粵台客語|Yue-Tai]] & [[:zh:海陸客語|Hailu]] |script=[[Latin script|Latin]] ([[Pha̍k-fa-sṳ]]), [[Han characters]] ([[Traditional Chinese|traditional]]) |nation={{flagu|Taiwan}} |minority=[[Taiwan]] ([[de facto]] status as one of the statutory languages for {{cn-span|public transport announcements|date=November 2018}} and for the [[naturalization]] test;Article 6 of the [http://www.ris.gov.tw/zh_TW/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=2a89733e-e3e3-4f28-8f7b-84dff55777d5&groupId=10157 Standards for Identification of Basic Language Abilities and General Knowledge of the Rights and Duties of Naturalized Citizens] government sponsor of Hakka-language television station) |isoexception=dialect |iso6=htia |agency=[[Hakka Affairs Council]] |glotto=none |glottorefname= |lingua=79-AAA-gap | map = Taiwanese Hakka usage map in 2010.svg | mapcaption = Proportion of residents aged 6 or older using Hakka at home in Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen & Matsu in 2010 }} '''Taiwanese Hakka''' is a group of [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka dialects]] spoken in [[Taiwan]], and mainly used by [[Hakka people|people of Hakka ancestry]]. Taiwanese Hakka is divided into five main dialects: [[Sixian dialect|Sixian]] ({{zh|t=四縣腔|labels=no}}), Hailu ({{zh|t=海陸腔|labels=no}}), Dabu ({{zh|t=大埔腔|labels=no}}), [[Raoping dialect|Raoping]] ({{zh|t=饒平腔|labels=no}}), and Zhao'an ({{zh|t=詔安腔|labels=no}}).{{cite web|url=http://www.hakka.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=110321&ctNode=2828&mp=2210&ps=|title=Amazing Hakka|date=2010-12-29|work=Hakka Affairs Council|accessdate=12 February 2016}} The most widely spoken of the five Hakka dialects in Taiwan are Sixian and Hailu.{{cite book |title=The Republic of China Yearbook 2010 |chapterurl=http://www.gio.gov.tw/taiwan-website/5-gp/yearbook/02People&Language.pdf |chapter=Chapter 2: People and Language |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805173731/http://www.gio.gov.tw/taiwan-website/5-gp/yearbook/02People%26Language.pdf |publisher=Government Information Office, Republic of China (Taiwan) |isbn=9789860252781 |page=42 |archivedate=2011-08-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The former, possessing 6 tones, originates from [[Meizhou]], [[Guangdong]], and is mainly spoken in [[Miaoli County|Miaoli]], [[Pingtung County|Pingtung]] and [[Kaohsiung]], while the latter, possessing 7 tones, originates from [[Haifeng County|Haifeng]] and [[Lufeng, Guangdong|Lufeng]], [[Guangdong]], and is concentrated around [[Hsinchu County|Hsinchu]]. ==Hakka-related tourist attractions in Taiwan== * [[Dongshih Hakka Cultural Park]] * [[Hakka Round House]] * [[Kaohsiung Hakka Cultural Museum]] * [[Liudui Hakka Cultural Park]] * [[Meinong Hakka Culture Museum]] * [[Miaoli Park]] * [[New Taipei City Hakka Museum]] * [[Pingtung Hakka Cultural Museum]] * [[Taipei Hakka Culture Hall]] * [[Taoyuan Hakka Culture Hall]] * [[Tuniu Hakka Cultural Museum]] ==See also== *[[Taiwanese Hakka Romanization System]] *[[Taiwanese languages]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web|script-title=zh:臺灣客家語常用詞辭典 |trans-title=Dictionary of Frequently-Used Taiwan Hakka |url=http://hakka.dict.edu.tw/hakkadict/index.htm |publisher=Ministry of Education, R.O.C. |date=2016 | language = zh-hant}} {{Languages of Taiwan}} {{Chinese language}} [[Category:Hakka Chinese]] [[Category:Languages of Taiwan]]
