Bot: Removing [[Commons:File:Guatemala Lynching.jpg]] ([[:File:Guatemala Lynching.jpg|en]]). It was deleted on Commons by [[:Commons:User:Sealle|Sealle]] (per [[Commons:Commons:Deletion requests/File:Guatemala Lynching.jpg]]).
revision.text:
[[File:090628 mujer limpiando zompopos de mayo.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A woman from Guatemala.]] [[File:Guatemala_(orthographic_projection).svg|thumb|right|250px|[[Guatemala]] is a country of approximately 15 million people, situated in [[Central America]], bordered by Mexico to the north and west, the Pacific Ocean to the southwest, Belize to the northeast, the Caribbean to the east, Honduras to the east and El Salvador to the southeast.]] {{Violence against women}} {{Women in society sidebar}} '''Violence against women in Guatemala''' reached severe levels during the long-running [[Guatemalan Civil War]] (1960-1996), and the continuing impact of that conflict has contributed to the present high levels of [[violence against women]] in that nation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Villareal|first=Ryan|title=Half The Sky Is Falling: Systemic Violence Against Women In Guatemala Ripples From Brutal Civil War|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/half-sky-falling-systemic-violence-against-women-guatemala-ripples-brutal-civil-war-1024178#|accessdate=17 June 2013|newspaper=International Business Times|date=January 18, 2013 <!-- 5:58 AM --> }}</ref> During the armed conflict, [[rape]] was used as a [[Wartime sexual violence|weapon of war]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-21053075|title=Guatemala shock as two murdered girls found on street|work=BBC News}}</ref>
==Femicide== [[Femicide]] in [[Guatemala]] is an extremely serious problem. According to a 2012 report by the [[Small Arms Survey]], Guatemala has the third highest rate of femicide in the world, behind only [[El Salvador]] and [[Jamaica]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trust.org/slideshow/?id=59ccc3c0-c719-467e-bf0b-622739b34ef4|title=Struggling with femicide and impunity for crimes against women in Central America|author=Thomson Reuters Foundation|publisher=}}</ref> According to official figures, 560 women were murdered in the country in 2012, 631 in 2011 and 695 in 2010, though the exact number is not known.
Murders rarely result in any conviction and often are not properly investigated; less than 4 percent of all homicide cases result in conviction for the perpetrators.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/time-end-inaction-over-killings-women-guatemala-2013-01-17|title=Time to end the inaction over killings of women in Guatemala|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/guatemala-s-war-women-2013-01-21|title=Guatemala|publisher=}}</ref> Perpetrators are confident they will get away with murder, in part because of the "[[machismo]]" culture in Latin America. This culture allows women to be treated as objects rather than humans; equality and basic rights granted to men are not even in question for women.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 'Femicide' on the rise in Central America|url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/femicide-rise-central-america-article-1.1552233|website = NY Daily News|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> [[Rape culture]] and [[victim blaming]] are the tactics that go along with machismo, and both men and women largely agree with the misogynistic tendencies that have survived for so long.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Guatemala: Gender-based violence at epidemic levels - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/02/world/iyw-guatemala-gender-violence/index.html|website = CNN|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
==Attacks on women activists== Women who work as public activists, such as human rights defenders, including activists working to protect land and natural resources, face violence, threats, reprisal, and illegal arrests. Such acts are often committed by government authorities and security forces.<ref name="auto">{{cite book|url=http://nobelwomensinitiative.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/Report_AmericasDelgation-2012.pdf|title=From Survivors to Defenders: Women Confronting Violence in Mexico, Honduras & Guatemala|publisher=Nobel Women's Initiative}}</ref>
In Guatemala, women activists experience at least one attack each day on average, and an estimated eighty-three percent of these activists are land and natural resource defenders.<ref name="auto"/> Factors such as foreign investments, typically in mining, have created conflict with native communities fighting to defend their land rights and natural resources. As a result, indigenous women are primary victims of threats and violence.<ref name="auto"/> Findings from 2012 to 2014 showed that among female human rights defenders in Central America and Mexico, women defending land from mining operations were the most susceptible to gender violence, including risk of assassination. Guatemala is considered one of the ten most dangerous countries for environmental activists in the world, but accountability for such crimes remains a challenge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Mining-in-Guatemala-Abuses-Womens-Rights-Activists-Say-20151210-0046.html|title=Mining in Guatemala Abuses Women's Rights, Activists Say|last=hg-TP-gp|first=teleSUR /|access-date=2016-12-06}}</ref>
==Sexual violence== Sexual violence is widespread in Guatemala. There are about 10,000 cases of reported rape per year, but the total number is likely much higher because of under-reporting due to social stigma. According to ''[[Doctors without Borders]]'', "Survivors [of sexual violence] are stigmatized and they cannot easily find treatment in Guatemala yet. There are no resources and too little comprehension of patients’ needs by the doctors."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news-stories/field-news/guatemala-treating-sexual-violence-breaking-cycle-fear|title=Guatemala: Treating Sexual Violence, Breaking the Cycle of Fear|work=MSF USA}}</ref> The nation's health care institutions are ill-equipped and unwilling to provide adequate care for the thousands of women victimized by sexual violence each year.<ref name="doctorswithoutborders.org">{{Cite news|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news-stories/field-news/guatemala-treating-sexual-violence-breaking-cycle-fear|title=Guatemala: Treating Sexual Violence, Breaking the Cycle of Fear|date=2009-07-20|newspaper=MSF USA|access-date=2017-01-07}}</ref>
=== Sexual violence against adolescent girls === Many survivors are adolescent girls, leading to Guatemala having the highest [[teen pregnancy]] and [[preteen pregnancy]] rates in Latin America.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Guatemala has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in Latin America, and it’s getting worse -|url = http://www.ticotimes.net/2014/06/16/guatemala-has-the-highest-teenage-pregnancy-rate-in-latin-america-and-its-getting-worse|website = The Tico Times {{!}} Costa Rica News {{!}} Travel {{!}} Real Estate|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> Girls as young as 10 years old are impregnated by rape, and they usually carry these pregnancies to birth. Most of these instances of sexual violence are perpetrated by the girl's father or other close male relative (89%). These men do not suffer consequences largely because of the lack of education, poverty, and lack of social respect for women.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Fathers rape with impunity, fuelling Guatemala's teen pregnancies: rights group|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/02/us-guatemala-teenage-pregnancy-idUSKCN0RW22D20151002|newspaper = Reuters|date = 2015-10-02|access-date = 2015-10-26}}</ref> According to photo activist Linda Forsell,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Raped, Pregnant Girls Are The Focus Of This Searing Photo Project|url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/jessicalima/raped-pregnant-girls-are-the-focus-of-this-searing-photo-pro#.bcL0ZqXAE|website = BuzzFeed|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> most young girls face expulsion from school if they are visibly pregnant.
=== Sexual Violence as a War Tactic === Sexual violence is often used as a tactic in war, and many women, particularly women from indigenous tribes, often become sex slaves to soldiers and are subjected to rape and other forms of sexual violence.<ref name="unwomen.org">{{Cite news|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2016/3/guatemala-victory-against-sexual-violence-in-armed-conflict|title=Landmark ruling in Guatemala a victory against sexual violence in armed conflict|newspaper=UN Women|access-date=2017-01-07}}</ref> When a community is occupied or destroyed, an entire community of women may be subjected to rape and sexual or domestic slavery, affecting the prosperity and health of the community after a conflict’s end.<ref name="unwomen.org"/>
In February 2016, the Sepur Zarco trial convicted two ex-soldiers of crimes against humanity for their sexual abuse of 11 indigenous [[Q'eqchi' people|Q’eqchi’]] women, the forced disappearance of the women’s husbands, and the murder of a woman and her two daughters.<ref name="unwomen.org"/> Expert witnesses called by the prosecution included Brazilian feminist academic [[Rita Segato]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ijmonitor.org/2016/02/former-military-commissioner-accuses-reyes-giron-of-ordering-gang-rape/|title=Former Military Commissioner Accuses Reyes Girón of Ordering Gang Rape|date=25 February 2016|author=Jo-Marie Burt|website=International Justice Monitor|access-date=9 September 2018}}</ref> The women of the Q’eqchi” community received substantial reparations for the damage done by the convicted soldiers. This is the first time a case of sexual slavery during armed conflict has been considered in court. In Guatemala, it was the first time any form of sexual violence during a conflict had been settled in court.<ref name="unwomen.org"/>
=== Long-Term Health Problems === Common health problems that victims of sexual assault in Guatemala often suffer include HIV/AIDS, unwanted pregnancy, Hepatitis B, syphilis, Chlamydia, and Gonorrhoea. Because health care is not readily accessible and education about sexual violence not prevalent, avoidable and treatable health problems often go untreated.<ref name="doctorswithoutborders.org"/>
The emotional and psychological impact of sexual violence often requires professional health care to treat, but the stigma surrounding sexual violence makes it difficult for people to discuss.
=== International Organizations. === International organizations like Doctors Without Borders try to fill the gap in Guatemala's health care and provide assistance to victims of sexual violence. In 2007, Doctors Without Borders opened a clinic in Guatemala City that provides comprehensive care for such victims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news-stories/field-news/guatemala-treating-sexual-violence-breaking-cycle-fear|title=Guatemala: Treating Sexual Violence, Breaking the Cycle of Fear|last=Baldini|first=Frederic|date=2008|website=Doctors Without Borders|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref> The organization is also implementing educational programs in Guatemala City that aim to end the prevalence of sexual violence there.
The Center for Gender and Refugee Studies investigates and reports on sexual violence in Guatemala, working with human rights advocates, government groups, and community groups based in Guatemala.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cgrs.uchastings.edu/our-work/central-america-femicides-and-gender-based-violence|title=Central America: Femicide's and Gender-based Violence|last=|first=|date=|website=The Center for Gender and Refugee Studies|publisher=|access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref> They have published papers on the ineffectiveness of Guatemala’s Law Against Femicide and Other Forms of Violence Against Women, passed in 2008. They also provide resources for attorney representing female victims of sexual violence, and help advocates in Guatemala implement laws that prevent sexual violence. They also educate countries around the world about the prevalence of sexual violence in Guatemala, so that international pressure can be put on the country to prevent sexual violence against women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cgrs.uchastings.edu/our-work/central-america-femicides-and-gender-based-violence|title=Central America: Femicides and Gender-Based Violence|last=|first=|date=|website=Center for Gender and Refugee Studies|publisher=|access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref>
==Effects of militarization== The increased militarization of Guatemala has resulted in abuse and mistreatment of the people of Guatemala.<ref name=":0" /> Militarism spreads a perception of brutality and makes it easier to access weapons, which makes the rates of domestic violence against women go up.<ref name="auto"/> Guatemala’s military has a hefty history of human rights violations.<ref name="auto1">{{cite journal|title=Rethinking the Drug War in Central America and Mexico|url=http://www.cipamericas.org/archives/11315}}</ref> Murders, torture, and missing people became a daily reality for people in Guatemala.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Archibald|first1=Jennifer|title=Human Rights in Guatemala|url=http://www.du.edu/korbel/hrhw/researchdigest/latinamerica/guatemala.pdf}}</ref> Most findings show that in communities where there is an army present tend to have more violence against women.<ref name="auto"/> The Guatemalan military is also correlated with corruption. Recent records state that the government and military are often associated with criminal activity.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=musalo|first1=Karen|title=Crime without Punishment|url=http://cgrs.uchastings.edu/sites/default/files/Musalo_Bookey_CrimesWithoutPunishment_2013.pdf}}</ref>
=== Increased military presence to combat the War on Drugs === Militarization came to Guatemala in the early 1980s.<ref name="auto"/> In Guatemala, as well as in other parts of Latin America, there is an intense "war on drugs", that is a conflict between state forces and drug cartels, which has taken a violent turn. As a result of the war on drugs, there is a widespread presence of the military throughout the country thanks to three military bases in known drug trafficking areas.<ref name="auto2">{{cite journal|last1=Gagne|first1=David|title=UN Chastises Guatemala on Militarization of Security|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/un-chastises-guatemala-on-militarization-of-security}}</ref> [[Jody Williams]], a [[Nobel Peace Prize]] recipient, said, "The war on drugs and increased militarization in Mexico, Honduras and Guatemala is becoming a war on women."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Nobel Peace Laureates call for concerted action to protect frontlines human rights defenders|url=http://www.friendshipamericas.org/nobel-peace-laureates-call-concerted-action-protect-frontlines-human-rights-defenders}}</ref>
=== The military's role in public safety initiatives === From 2006 to 2011, the budget the military was allotted went from sixty-three million United States dollars to one hundred and seventy-five million dollars.<ref name="auto"/> [[Otto Pérez Molina]] became the first military official to be elected as president.<ref name="auto1"/> Shortly after being elected president in 2012, Pérez increased the role of the military in fighting crime.<ref name="auto2"/> Soldiers now are assigned public safety duties that would normally be reserved for police forces.
As of 2013 there were twenty-one thousand troops deployed to assist in public safety duties.<ref name="auto1"/>
==Violence against indigenous women== Amerindian (indigenous) women in Guatemala face high levels of violence by the military, and state authorities.<ref>http://upsidedownworld.org/main/guatemala-archives-33/5113-indigenous-women-in-guatemala-demand-end-to-state-of-prevention</ref><ref>http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Indigenous-Women-Fight-Racism-and-Sexism-in-Guatemalan-Congress-20160411-0022.html</ref><ref>http://www.latina.com/lifestyle/our-issues/violence-indigenous-women-guatemala-trial</ref> It is very difficult for indigenous women to obtain justice. Many of them have not received school education, and live in extreme poverty. Girls in indigenous communities do not attend school because of the distance from their homes to school.<ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/02/world/iyw-guatemala-gender-violence/</ref> Indigenous population is estimated at 39.8% of Gatemala's population (in 2012).<ref name=INE>{{cite web |url=http://www.ine.gob.gt/sistema/uploads/2014/02/26/5eTCcFlHErnaNVeUmm3iabXHaKgXtw0C.pdf |title=Caracterización estadística República de Guatemala 2012|accessdate=2014-11-02 |publisher=INE | archiveurl=http://www.ine.gob.gt/ | archivedate= November 2012| deadurl= no}}</ref> High illiteracy rates and the fact that they do not speak Spanish makes the justice system limited for them.<ref name=":0"/>
During the civil war, many indigenous women were forced into [[sexual slavery]] by the military. In 2016, a court in Guatemala ordered two former military officers to pay over $1m (£710,000) to 11 indigenous women whom they held as sex slaves during the civil war.<ref>http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/guatemala-sex-slaves-mayan-women-win-1m-compensation-civil-war-military-atrocities-1547319</ref>
==Child marriage and pregnancy== Early marriage for girls is common in Guatemala; the country has one of the highest rates of [[child marriage]] in Latin America.<ref name="girlsnotbrides.org">{{cite web|title=Guatemala - Child Marriage Around The World. Girls Not Brides|url=http://www.girlsnotbrides.org/child-marriage/guatemala/|website=Girls Not Brides|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref> As of 2015, men and women must be at least 18 years of age to marry; sometimes exceptions can be made by judges for girls to be married at 16. Previously, girls could be married at 14 and boys could be married at 16. The age was increased and made the same regardless of gender in hopes to hold both men and women to the same standard.<ref name="girlsnotbrides.org"/> It is estimated that 7% of girls are married before 15 years of age and 30% by 18 years of age.<ref name="girlsnotbrides.org"/> Rates are even higher in rural areas where 53% of females are married before they are 18.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Edie|title=Guatemala raises legal marriage age to 18 {{!}} Too Young Too Wed|url=http://tooyoungtowed.org/blog/guatemala-raises-legal-marriage-age-to-18/|website=tooyoungtowed.org}}</ref> Some reasons for early marriage is poverty, rigid gender norms, access to education, and tradition. Older men also provide more financial support to these girls. After marriage, girls are expected to start a family and face a lot of pressure to get pregnant.<ref name="girlsnotbrides.org"/> Teen mothers account for a quarter of births in Guatemala.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moloney|first1=Anastasia|title=Guatemala bans child marriage, big change for rural areas|url=http://news.trust.org//item/20151111184347-bhe0h/?source=jtOtherNews3|website=news.trust.org|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref> "Complications in pregnancy and childbirth are the second highest cause of death for 15- to 19-year-old girls globally".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/11/guatemala-bans-child-marriage|title=Guatemala bans child marriage but 'cultural shift' required, advocates say|last=Reuters|date=2015-11-11|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
==Mob violence== Guatemala is ranked the 25th most violent country in the world and Guatemalan police have a reputation for being non-responsive to the high crime rates.<ref name="panampost.com">{{Cite news|url=https://panampost.com/pep-balcarcel/2015/06/08/beaten-exiled-or-burned-alive-mob-justice-in-guatemala/|title=Beaten, Exiled, or Burned Alive: Mob Justice in Guatemala|date=2015-06-08|newspaper=PanAm Post|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> The lack of security within the government is what encouraged the start of mobs turning to vigilante justice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/27/americas/guatemala-girl-burned-mob/index.html|title=Video of mob burning teen in Guatemala spurs outrage|last=CNN|first=Annie Rose Ramos, Catherine E. Shoichet and Richard Beltran|website=CNN|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> Unfortunately, a lot of the crime associated with these mobs is just as bad as the crime they claim they are attempting to prevent. Most of the locals keep quiet for fear of being targeted by these groups themselves, and many of the people participating in the violence are forced to do so.<ref name="panampost.com"/>
As in other countries where the population does not trust the authorities, people in Guatemala often enforce informal 'justice' by subjecting to violence and even murdering individuals whom they believe have violated moral standards. For example, in 2015, a 16-year-old girl was beaten and burned alive by a Guatemalan lynch mob after reportedly being accused of being part of a group that killed a taxi driver.<ref>http://www.smh.com.au/world/girl-16-burnt-alive-by-guatemalan-lynch-mob-20150525-gh8xyk.html</ref> <ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/27/americas/guatemala-girl-burned-mob/</ref>
==Problems within the justice system== After years of violence, dictatorship, and conflict, Guatemala's public institutions are ineffective, including its justice system. Lack of funding has made the law-enforcement departments ineffective and, seeing how unlikely it is to be charged, criminals are encouraged to continue normalizing this widespread, unchecked violence. Based on the numbers of incidents actually reported and taken to court, only 3% result in any sort of court resolution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cgrs.uchastings.edu/our-work/central-america-femicides-and-gender-based-violence|title=Central America: Femicides and Gender-Based Violence|last=|first=|date=|website=Center for Gender and Refugee Studies|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref> Authorities do not always conduct proper investigations. A minority of the reported crimes against women go to trial, and even fewer result in a conviction. According to [[Nobel Women's Initiative]], in the 1980s, 200,000 people were murdered, and thousands of women were raped. Many cases similar to these have not gone to trial.<ref name="auto"/> Of the complaints about violence against women that were registered in 2010 by the Judicial Department, only one percent of them resulted in sentencing.
Law enforcement often fails to investigate in a timely manner and blame the victims of the case.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Musalo|first1=Karen|title=Crimes Without Punishment|url=http://cgrs.uchastings.edu/sites/default/files/Musalo_Bookey_CrimesWithoutPunishment_2013.pdf}}</ref> Many women abandon their cases because the stress and hardship put onto them.<ref name=":0"/> Without proper trials, investigations, and sentencing, the violence towards women will progressively increase.
Women are often murdered or subjected to violence by family members such as fathers, brothers, stepfathers and husbands,<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-34978330</ref> but when they try to report a crime that was done by family members, the women themselves are often treated as criminals for complaining.<ref name="auto"/> Discrimination in the justice system is one of the many problems women face in Guatemala. The justice system discriminates against others' race, class, sex, and ethnicity.<ref name="auto"/> Discrimination is worst for women who are poor, migrant, young, lesbian, and those that demand justice.<ref name="auto"/>
There is a lack of female representation in the political system.<ref name="auto3">{{cite journal|last1=Yan|first1=Sarah|title=Violence Against Women in Guatemala|url=http://www.borgenmagazine.com/violence-women-guatemala/}}</ref> As of 2015, only 13.9% of members of Parliament were women.<ref>http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/classif.htm</ref>
The justice system is limited for people who do not speak Spanish.<ref name=":0"/> This means that the women must be educated in order to protect their rights. The 2008 law against femicide and other forms of violence against women has enforced people to treat women equally. The 2008 law addressed the private and public crimes in Guatemala.<ref name=":0"/> Women in Guatemala are often uninformed of their rights and do not have the courage to report the crimes committed against them.<ref name="auto3"/>
==Legislation== Guatemala is a country that has one of the most prevalent rates of violence against women in the world.<ref>http://lap.sagepub.com/content/41/1/124.full.pdf+html</ref> Instances of gendered violence in Guatemala include domestic violence, sexual violence, human trafficking, incest, and femicide (the deliberate killing of women). In response to violence against women, the government has passed laws and created agencies in order to stunt the high rates of gendered violence in Guatemala in the 1990s: in 1996 it enacted ''Ley para prevenir, sancionar y erradicar la violencia intrafamiliar'' (Law on the Prevention, Punishment and Eradication of Domestic Violence).<ref>http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/population/domesticviolence/guatemala.dv.96.pdf</ref> In 2008, it enacted ''Ley contra el Femicidio y otras Formas de Violencia Contra la Mujer '' (Law against Femicide and Other Forms of Violence Against Women),<ref>http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/population/domesticviolence/guatemala.violence.08.pdf</ref> and in 2009 it enacted ''Ley contra la violencia sexual, explotación y trata de personas'' (Law against Sexual Violence, Exploitation and Trafficking in Persons).<ref>http://www.protectionproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/GUATEMALA-SPANISH.pdf</ref>
=== Procurador de los Derechos Humanos === In 2008, the [[:es:Procuraduría de los Derechos Humanos (Guatemala)|Procurador de los Derechos Humanos]] (Human Rights Ombudsman) was created, which is an agency that operates with the intention of enforcing citizens' cooperation with human rights laws. Despite these efforts made by Guatemala's government, the number of women who experience gendered violence persists. The ineffectiveness of Procurador de los Derechos Humanos is a result of a multitude of factors including the weakness of the justice system, a lack of clarity surrounding laws made regarding gendered violence, and the absence of free institutions that would aid victims.<ref>http://search.proquest.com/docview/1629401033/</ref> Despite the intentions of enacting Procurador de los Derechos Humanos, the full potential of its efficiency has not yet been reached.
=== Legal age of marriage === More recently, social groups advocating for gender equality in Guatemala helped reform the age at which a girl is able to legally be married. The Angélica Fuentes Foundation and Girl Up (a United Nations youth foundation) together put forth an initiative to change the legal age of marriage in Guatemala from 14 to 18. These advocates had integral roles in the passing of the legislation in January 2016. The leaders of both The Angélica Fuentes Foundation and Girl Up stated that their main goal of pushing for a higher marriage age was to aid the children in Guatemala.<ref name="Get it @ ASU">http://www.marketwatch.com/story/gender-equality-update---angelica-fuentes-and-un-girl-up-push-legislation-in-guatemala-to-change-legal-age-of-marriage-from-14-to-18-years-old-2016-10-03-121603825</ref> Young girls often would be forced to give up their education and be constricted to a life devoted to marriage, however with the marriage age raised young women would be free to pursue other interests. The leader of The Angélica Fuentes Foundation states that it is her hope that this initiative promotes gender equality and an increase in opportunity for young girls in Guatemala, as well as in other Latin American countries.<ref name="Get it @ ASU"/>

'''William Wallace "Bill" Norton, Jr.''' (September 24, 1925 – October 1, 2010) was an American [[screenwriter]] particularly notable for his collaborations with [[Burt Reynolds]]Ayres Jr., B. Drummond. [https://www.nytimes.com/1975/11/01/archives/good-ole-boy-stars-in-dixie-filmmaking-boom.html "'Good Ole Boy' Stars in Dixie Film-Making Boom"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 1, 1975. Accessed September 27, 2018. Later in life, he was convicted of [[arms trafficking|gun running]] in [[France]] when he tried to send arms from the United States to the [[Irish National Liberation Army]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. After being released from prison, he moved to [[Nicaragua]], where he shot and killed an intruder in his [[Managua]] home. He later spent a year living in [[Cuba]] but became disillusioned with [[Communism]] and was reportedly smuggled from [[Mexico]] into the U.S. by his ex-wife.{{citation |author=Weber, Bruce |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/09/movies/09norton.html |title=William Norton, Writer Wilder Than His Movies, Is Dead at 85 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 8, 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-10 }}{{citation |author=Woo, Elaine |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/oct/10/local/la-me-william-norton-20101010 |title=William W. 'Bill' Norton dies at 85; screenwriter became gunrunner |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 10, 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-11 }}{{citation |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118025458.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |title='Scalphunters' scribe Norton dies: He was arrested for running guns |journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 10, 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-11 }} ==Early life== Norton was born to Andrena "Rena" (''née'' Callahan; March 20, 1902 – October 16, 1989California Death Index. - California Department of Health Services Office of Health Information. - SS#: 571-20-8989.
{{Find a Grave|19316681|Andrena "Rena" Norton}}) and William Wallace Norton (February 14, 1900 – July 18, 1973NOTE: The California Death Index (CDI) lists the date of birth for W. W. Norton, Sr. as February 12, 1901, while the Social Security Death Index (SSDI) shows February 14, 1900. - SS#: 564-07-0696.
{{Find a Grave|19404418|W. W. Norton, Sr.}}) in [[Ogden, Utah]], where his parents owned a ranch which they lost at the start of the [[Great Depression]]. His family moved to [[Berkeley, California]], and then later to [[El Monte, California|El Monte]]. He attended [[El Monte High School]], where he was class president. ===World War II=== During [[World War II]], Norton enlisted in the [[United States Army]] and served in Europe as an infantry officer with [[5th Infantry Regiment (United States)|5th Infantry]], [[71st Infantry Division (United States)|71st Infantry Division]] with Patton's Third Army.http://jeffcramer.blogspot.com.au/2010/01/very-candid-conversation-with-william.html. He started writing, using his life experience of growing up poor and serving in the military, and some of his plays were produced by local theater companies. He joined the [[Communist Party]] in his youth and in 1958 was called to testify before the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]], though he did not name anyone. ==Hollywood== He wrote for the television series ''[[The Big Valley]]'', which was broadcast from 1965 to 1968. His big screen breakthrough came with his script for the 1968 film ''[[The Scalphunters]]'', set in the antebellum West, with the movie starring [[Burt Lancaster]], [[Ossie Davis]] and [[Shelley Winters]]. Other screenplays that Norton wrote included the Angie Dickinson vehicle ''[[Big Bad Mama]]'', produced by [[Roger Corman]], and the [[John Wayne]] detective film ''[[Brannigan (film)|Brannigan]]'' (1975). He wrote the [[Burt Reynolds]] vehicles ''[[Sam Whiskey]]'', ''[[The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing (film)|The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing]]'', ''[[White Lightning (1973 film)|White Lightning]]'' and ''[[Gator (film)|Gator]]''. When asked by a nurse the day before he died if she would know any of Norton's films, he replied "I don't think your I.Q. is low enough". ==Ireland== After moving to Ireland in the mid-1980s, Norton was angered by attacks staged against Roman Catholic residents of [[Northern Ireland]]. He flew back to the U.S. and purchased a number of guns to bring back to supply the [[Irish National Liberation Army]] (INLA). Norton also purchased a camping van and had a hidden compartment made. The van was shipped aboard a Panamanian ship inside a container, from Los Angeles to the port at [[Rotterdam]].{{cite news |page=15 |title=Irish rifles found in van from U.S. |publisher=[[United Press International]] {UPI} |accessdate=2011-11-24 |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=June 12, 1986 }} The van, still inside the container, was then put on a truck and hauled from Rotterdam, through Belgium, to the port of [[Le Havre]], [[France]]. Authorities were watching the van, which had two submachine guns, 12 rifles, 23 revolvers and 2,200 rounds of ammunition in the hidden compartment. Norton and his wife, Eleanor, were arrested on June 11, 1986, trying to retrieve the vehicle and were both convicted. Also arrested with them were two INLA members, James MacLaughin and Sean Hughes, and also Hughes' girlfriend Susan May.{{cite book |author=[[Edward Mickolus|Mickolus, Edward F]].; and Susan L. Simmons |title=The Terrorist List |year=2011 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-0-313-37471-5 |pages=132 }} Susan May's two children, who were with her, were taken to a children's home. ===Prison=== In August 1987, William Norton, Hughes and MacLaughin were each sentenced to four years in prison, while Eleanor Norton was sentenced to three years with two of those suspended.{{citation |title=France Convicts L.A. Couple of Illegal Importing of Arms |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 5, 1987 }} Additionally, the group was forbidden to return to France for five years, and they were fined a total of [[United States dollar|US$]]81,700. Susan May was not convicted. Norton was released after 19 months while his wife served five months before her release on medical grounds. The couple were subject to a U.S. warrant on the gun smuggling charges and were granted asylum in [[Nicaragua]]. ==Central America and Cuba== After bandits broke into his house in [[Managua]], he was able to find a gun and shot and killed one of the robbers. He relocated to Cuba in the 1990s, but rapidly became disenchanted with life under Communism. He moved, this time to Mexico, and sought the help of his daughter and his first wife to bring him back into the United States. He met his family members in [[Tijuana]], and they smuggled him back across the U.S. border. He settled in [[Santa Barbara, California]], where he reportedly spent years worrying that the FBI would arrest him until a lawyer convinced him that he had nothing to worry about. He wrote a script, ''Exiled in America'', based on his experiences, which was produced by Paul Leder. ==Death== Norton died in Santa Barbara of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], aged 85, on October 1, 2010. He was survived by his second wife, Eleanor, as well as by two daughters and a son, writer-director [[Bill L. Norton]]. His first marriage, to the former Betty Conklin, had ended in divorce. ==Filmography== *''[[The Grass Eater]]'' (1961) - writer, producer *''[[Five Minutes to Love]]'' (1963) - writer *''[[How to Succeed with Girls]]'' (1964) - writer, producer *''[[The Farmer's Other Daughter]]'' (1965) - writer, producer *''[[The Big Valley]]'' (1965–69) (TV series) - writer *''[[The Scalphunters]]'' (1968) - writer *''[[Sam Whiskey]]'' (1968) - writer *''[[The McKenzie Break]]'' (1970) - writer *''[[Marigold Man]]'' (1970) - writer, producer *''[[The Hunting Party (1971 film)|The Hunting Party]]'' (1971) - writer *''[[I Dismember Mama]]'' (1972) - writer *''[[The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing (film)|The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing]]'' (1973) - writer (uncredited) *''[[Trader Horn (1973 film)|Trader Horn]]'' (1973) - writer *''[[White Lightning (1973 film)|White Lightning]]'' (1973) - writer *''[[Big Bad Mama]]'' (1974) - writer *''[[Brannigan (film)|Brannigan]]'' (1975) - writer *''[[A Small Town in Texas]]'' (1976) - writer *''[[Moving Violation (film)|Moving Violation]]'' (1976) - writer *''[[Gator (film)|Gator]]'' (1976) - writer *''[[Day of the Animals]]'' (1977) - writer *''[[Night of the Juggler]]'' (1980) - writer *''[[Dirty Tricks]]'' (1981) - writer *''[[September Gun]]'' (1983) (TV movie) - writer *''[[The Eleventh Commandment (1986 film)|The Eleventh Commandment]]'' (1986) - writer *''[[Big Bad Mama II]]'' (1987) - original characters *''[[Exiled in America]]'' (1992) - based on his play ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0636151/ William Norton] at [[IMDB]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Norton, William W.}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American communists]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II‎]] [[Category:American male screenwriters]] [[Category:Writers from Ogden, Utah]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:People from El Monte, California]] [[Category:Screenwriters from California]] [[Category:Screenwriters from Utah]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox women by region | image = Haitian Elegance (8222064720).jpg | caption = A Haitian woman | gii = 0.599 (2013) | gii_rank = 132nd out of 152 | gii_ref = <ref name=gii>{{cite web|title=Table 4: Gender Inequality Index|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/table-4-gender-inequality-index|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> | matdeath = 350 (2010) | womparl = 3.5% (2013) | femed = 22.5% (2012) | womlab = 60.6% (2012) | ggg = <!-- Global Gender Gap, value and year, e.g. "0.6442 (2012)" --> | ggg_rank = <!-- Global Gender Gap, rank --> | ggg_ref = <!-- Global Gender Gap, source; for 2013 <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> --> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} {{Feminism sidebar}} '''Women in Haiti''' have equal [[constitution of Haiti|constitutional]]<ref>[http://www.haiti.org/constitu/constabl.htm Constitution of the Republic of Haiti], Title III: "Art. 17: All Haitians, regardless of sex or marital status, who have attained twenty-one years of age may exercise their political and civil rights if they meet the other conditions prescribed by the Constitution and by the law. Art. 18: Haitians shall be equal before the law, subject to the special advantages conferred on native-born Haitians who have never renounced their nationality."</ref> rights as men in the [[economy of Haiti|economic]], [[Politics of Haiti|political]], [[Culture of Haiti|cultural]] and social fields, as well as in the family.
However, the reality in Haiti is quite far from the law: "political, economic and social features of Haiti negatively affect most Haitians, but Haitian women experience additional barriers to the full enjoyment of their basic rights due to predominant social beliefs that they are inferior to men and a historical pattern of discrimination and violence against them based on their sex. Discrimination against women is a structural feature in Haitian society and culture that has subsisted throughout its history, both in times of peace and unrest."<ref>Report of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR)on "The Right of Women in Haiti to be Free from Violence and Discrimination." OEA/Ser.L/V/II, Doc. 64, 10 March 2009.</ref>
==Women and society== Some Haitian scholars argue that Haitian peasant women are often less restricted socially than women in Western societies or even in comparison to more westernized elite Haitian women.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel">{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=38|edition=2nd}}</ref> They attribute this fact to the influence of African matriarcal systems and of the [[Haitian Vodou]] religion which places women at the center of society contrary to purely Judeo-Christian systems.<ref <ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel 2">{{cite book |last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=37|edition=2nd}}</ref> Women priests (named [[Mambo (Vodou)|mambo]]s) play equal roles to male priests or [[Houngan]] in Haitian vodou.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel"/>
The sexual equality inherent to Haitian vodou translates into the inclusion of women in all aspects of society.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=41|edition=2nd}}</ref> Peasant women specifically, because of their proximity to vodou, have traditionally played a crucial role in Haitian life.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=40|edition=2nd}}</ref> Compared to their Latin-American counterparts, the participation of Haitian women in agriculture, commerce and industry has been high.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> During the US occupation of Haiti (1915-1934) peasant women actively participated in guerilla warfare and anti-US intelligence gathering to free the country.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Because of their involvement in commerce, Haitian peasant women have accumulated resources independent of their mates in contrast to more westernized elite Haitian women.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=44|edition=2nd}}</ref>
==Political representation== [[File:Michèle Pierre-Louis-2009 (2).jpg|thumb|[[Michele Pierre-Louis]], former Prime Minister has proven a fervent promoter of women's rights in [[Haiti]] ]]
The Haitian government contains a Ministry of Women's Affairs, but it also lacks the resources to address issues such as violence against women and harassment in the workplace. A number of political figures such as [[Michele Pierre-Louis]], Haiti's second female Prime Minister, have adopted a determined agenda in order to fight inequalities and persecutions against women. Her position in office as Prime Minister has had positive effect on female political leadership in a country where the percentage of women in government at ministerial level was 25% in 2005.<ref>[http://hdrstats.undp.org/en/countries/data_sheets/cty_ds_HTI.html UNDP 2007/2008 Human Development Report, Haiti Factsheet]</ref>
== History of the Haitian women's movement ==
A [[women's movement]] emerged in Haiti in the 1930s during an economic crisis which is thought to have forced some middle-class Haitian women to work outside the home for the first time unlike peasant women who had always done so.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel"/> This was also a time at which more elite women began to pursue post-secondary education and when [[L'Université D'Etat d'Haiti]] opened its doors to women.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel"/> The first Haitian woman to receive a secondary education graduated during this period in 1933.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel"/>
One of the first established feminist organizations in Haiti was called the Ligue Féminine d'Action Sociale ([[Feminine League for Social Action]]) and was created in 1934.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|pages=38–39|edition=2nd}}</ref> Its mostly elite initial members included: [[Madeleine Sylvain]], [[Alice Garoute]], [[Fernande Bellegarde]], [[Thérèse Hudicourt]], [[Alice Mathon]], [[Marie-Thérèse Colimon]], [[Marie-Thérèse Poitevien]].<ref name="Breached Citadel 39">{{cite book|last1=Bellegarde-Smith|first1=Patrick|title=Haiti: The Breached Citadel|date=2004|publisher=Canadian Scholars Press|location=Ontario|isbn=1-55130-268-3|page=39|edition=2nd}}</ref> The Ligue was banned by the government two months after its founding.<ref name="Breached Citadel 39"/> The league was reestablished when it agreed to study its goals instead of immediately implementing them.<ref name="Breached Citadel 39"/> The league is credited for the granting of voting rights for women in 1957.<ref name="Breached Citadel 39"/>
In 1950, writer and feminist [[Paulette Poujol-Oriol]] joined the league. She later served as President of the League from 1997 until her death on March 11, 2011. She was also a founding member of [[L'Alliance des Femmes Haitiennes]], an umbrella organization for more than 50 women's groups.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ulysse|first1=Gina Athéna|title=The Legacy of Haitian Feminist Paulette Poujol-Oriol|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2011/03/29/the-legacy-of-haitian-feminist-paulette-poujol-oriol/|website=Ms. Magazine Blog|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
Some women were appointed to government leadership positions under François Duvalier: [[Rosalie Adolphe]] (aka [[Madame Max Adolphe]]) was appointed head of the secret police ([[Volontaires de La Sécurité Nationale]] or [[VSN]]) while [[Lydia O. Jeanty]] was named Under-Secretary of Labor in 1957 and [[Lucienne Heurtelou]], the widow of former President [[Dumarsais Estimé]], was Haiti's first female ambassador.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} [[Marie-Denise Duvalier]] nearly succeeded her father in 1971.<ref name="Haiti: The Breached Citadel"/>
== Sexual violence == {{main article|Sexual violence in Haiti}} Women in Haiti may suffer threats to their security and well-being because of rape, kid-napping and human trafficking. Women suffer the most from Haiti's chronic political instability.
Documented cases of politically motivated rape, massacres, forced disappearance, and violent assaults on entire neighborhoods increased greatly at the end of 1993 under the military dictatorship of [[Raoul Cédras]]. Reports from women's rights groups in Haiti revealed that women were targeted for abuse in ways and for reasons that men were not. Uniformed military personnel and their civilian allies threatened and attacked women's organizations for their work in defense of women's rights and subjected women to sex-specific abuse ranging from bludgeoning women's breasts to rape.<ref>Rape in Haiti: A Weapon of Terror, Human Rights Watch (HRW), 1 July 1994</ref>
The troubles before the [[2004 Haitian coup d'état|2004 coup]] were seen by most of the nationwide women's group as a reminder of the 1991–94 coup d'etat tactics with the use of rape, kidnapping and murders as forms of intimidation. If most of the feminist activists in Haiti campaigned for the election of [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] before his first term (1991–1995), many of them, especially intellectuals like [[Myriam Merlet]] or [[Magalie Marcelin]], condemned how the first democraticly elected president of Haiti ruled the country during his second term (2000–2004).<ref>{{cite web|author=Myriam Merlet|url=http://www.papda.org/article.php3?id_article=48 |title=Forces vives d'Haiti décrétent le Gouvernement Lavalas hors la loi|publisher=ENFOFANM|date=2 February 2004}}</ref> Other observers, more favorable of the Fanmi Lavalas party, were more incline to criticised the period after the coup as a "rewind" back to the same dictatorship tactics, "a terror campaign employing rape, murder and disappearance as tactics, and rapidly increasing insecurity undermining all economic activity of the informal sector."<ref>[http://www.ijdh.org/pdf/HaitiWomensDelJan05REPORT.pdf "Rewinding History: The Rights of Haitian Women" 2005 Report of the Let Haiti Live Women's Rights Delegation sponsored by the Ecumenical Program on Central America and the Caribbean (EPICA), January 2005. Obtained June 3rd 2009]</ref>
To this day, Haiti is "gripped by shocking levels of sexual violence against girls"; of particular concern is the number of cases of sexual violence reported in the run-up to or during Carnival.<ref>[http://www.amnestyusa.org/document.php?id=ENGUSA20081201001 Amnesty International, Press Release, Embargoed Until Noon, Thursday, Nov. 27, 2008. Obtained June 3, 2009]</ref>
Amnesty International<ref>Amnesty International launched a grass-roots campaign to [https://www.amnesty.org.hk/html/node/10234 send postcards to the Prime Minister of Haiti] to remind her of her duty to protect Haitian women. The text of the letter was such:
"Dear Prime Minister:
I am writing to you to express my deep concern at the levels of sexual violence perpetrated against girls in Haiti, particularly during the carnival period. While the true extent of sexual violence against girls is not known, every year, in Port-au-Prince alone, dozens of girls report being raped at gunpoint by groups of young men.
I therefore urge you and your government to implement all necessary measures to prevent rape and protect girls' right to live free from violence, to ensure that the perpetrators are brought to justice and that the victims receive adequate support and reparation.
Yours respectfully,"</ref> and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights<ref>Report of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) on "The Right of Women in Haiti to be Free from Violence and Discrimination." OEA/Ser.L/V/II, Doc. 64, 10 March 2009.</ref> have laid particular pressure on the duty of the state to act in due diligience necessary to prevent and eradicate violence and discrimination against women.
Though the [[MINUSTAH]] has come with a peace-keeping mandate, a number of cases have arisen where the UN soldiers were found to have abused women.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/11/02/news/UN-GEN-UN-Haiti-Sexual-Exploitation.php|title= 108 Sri Lankan peacekeepers in Haiti to be repatriated after claims they paid prostitutes |publisher=International Herald Tribune|date=2007-11-02}}</ref>
==Education== {{Further information|Education in Haiti}}
Women in Haiti do not benefit from an equal access to education. The rural-urban difference is also considerable as nearly 25% of the women in urban areas have finished secondary school, compared with less than 2 percent in rural areas. Though most Latin American countries have achieved universal or near universal [[primary education]] for all children, for Haiti primary education, the enrollment rate of boys was still somewhat higher than that of girls in 1987, but it is narrowing as the average growth enrollment has been significantly greater for girls than for boys.<ref>[https://books.google.ht/books?id=DL8uSGzj8YIC&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=women+education+haiti&source=bl&ots=S10CtoKMJ0&sig=0hfDEe1FG_iXgM9DctF8QWTOf3Q&hl=fr&ei=59cmSvW-GqCk8gTLurmBDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#PPA184,M1 Women's Education in Developing Countries: Barriers, Benefits, and Policies, pp.183–184. By Elizabeth M. King, M. Anne Hill. Published by World Bank Publications, 1998.] {{ISBN|0-8018-5828-3}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Sexual violence in Haiti]]
'''General:''' * [[Human rights in Haiti]]

Ithaca: Cornell UP, 2001 * ''Gender and Politics in Contemporary Haiti: The Duvalierist State, Transnationalism, and the Emergence of a New Feminism (1980–1990)'', Carolle Charles. {{Infobox recurring event | name = World Elephant Day | logo = | logo_caption = | image = Kissing Elephants.JPG | caption = Elephants | date = August 12 | frequency = Annually | location = Worldwide | established = {{Start date|2012|8|12|df=y}} | founder_name = Patricia Sims and the Elephant Reintroduction Foundation | website = {{URL|worldelephantday.org}} }}
'''World Elephant Day''' is an international annual event on August 12, dedicated to the preservation and protection of the world's [[elephants]]. Conceived in 2011 by Canadian filmmakers Patricia Sims and Michael Clark of Canazwest Pictures, and Sivaporn Dardarananda, Secretary-General of the [[Elephant Reintroduction Foundation]] in [[Thailand]], it was officially founded, supported and launched by Patricia Sims and the Elephant Reintroduction Foundation on August 12, 2012.<ref>[http://worldelephantday.org/about/elephant-reintroduction-foundation "Elephant Reintroduction Foundation"], ''World Elephant Day website''</ref> Since that time, Patricia Sims continues to lead and direct World Elephant Day, which is now supported by over 65 wildlife organizations<ref>[http://worldelephantday.org/associates "Associates"], ''World Elephant Day website''</ref> and many individuals in countries across the globe.<ref>Xinhua, [http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/803503.shtml "World Elephant Day brings attention to elephants' plight"], ''The Global Times'', 2013</ref><ref>Philip Mansbridge, [http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/philip-mansbridge/elephants-world-elephant-day_b_3739095.html "Is This Year's World Elephant Day the Last Chance for Elephants?"], ''The Huffington Post'', 2013</ref><ref>Raj Phukan, [http://www.assamtimes.org/node/8743 "World Elephant Day celebrated at Nagaon"], ''Assam Times'', 2013</ref><ref>Jennifer Viegas, [http://news.discovery.com/animals/endangered-species/elephants-get-help-from-unlikely-sources-is-it-enough-130812.htm "Elephants Get Unlikely Help -- But Is It Enough?"], ''Discovery News'', 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.chiangraitimes.com/world-elephant-day-thailand-must-shut-down-ivory-trade.html "World Elephant Day - Thailand Must Shut Down Ivory Trade"], ''Chiangrai Times'', 2013</ref><ref>[http://metro.co.uk/2013/08/12/12-years-until-elephants-are-all-wiped-out-as-one-dies-every-15-minutes-3919927/ "12 years until elephants are all wiped out as one dies every 15 minutes"], ''Metro'', 2013</ref><ref>Jason Bell, [http://africageographic.com/blog/world-elephant-day-time-to-take-stock/ "World Elephant Day - time to take stock"], ''Africa Geographic'', 2013</ref><ref>Bettina Wassener, [http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/10/mourning-the-elephants/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1& "Mourning the Elephants"], ''The New York Times'', 2012</ref><ref>Fidelis E. Satriastanti, [http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/blogs/globe-beat/sumatran-elephants-still-face-imminent-threats/ "Sumatran Elephants Still Face Imminent Threats"], ''Jakarta Globe'', 2013</ref>
== Mission ==
The goal of International Elephant Day is to create awareness of the urgent plight of [[African elephant|African]] and [[Asian elephant|Asian]] elephants, and to share knowledge and positive solutions for the better care and management of captive and wild elephants. African elephants are listed as "Vulnerable" and Asian elephants as "Endangered" on the [[IUCN Red List]] of threatened species.<ref>[http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/12392/0 "Loxodonta Africana (African elephant)"], ''IUCN''</ref><ref>[http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/summary/7140/0 "Elephas maximus (Asian elephant, Indian elephant)"], ''IUCN''</ref> One conservationist has stated that both African and Asian elephants face extinction within twelve years.<ref>John Ingham, [http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/421411/Elephants-extinct-within-12-years "Elephants 'extinct within 12 years'"], ''Express'', 2013</ref> The current population estimates are about 400,000 for African elephants and 40,000 for Asian elephants, although it has been argued that these numbers are much too high.<ref>[http://www.cites.org/sites/default/files/eng/com/sc/61/E61-44-02-A1.pdf "Status of Elephant Populations, Levels of Illegal Killing and the Trade in Ivory: A Report to the Standing Committee of CITES"], ''CITES''</ref>
== History ==
The first International Elephant Day was held on August 12, 2012.<ref>[http://worldelephantday.org/about "Overview"], ''World Elephant Day website''</ref><ref>Maria Sowter, [http://blog.frontiergap.com/blog/2012/8/9/world-elephant-day-this-sunday.html "World Elephant Day This Sunday"], ''Into The Wild'', 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/12/world-elephant-day-2012-photos_n_1770187.html "World Elephant Day 2012"], ''The Huffington Post'', 2012</ref> The film Return to the Forest, narrated by [[William Shatner]], is about the reintroduction of captive Asian elephants to the wild<ref>[http://www.amnh.org/explore/science-bulletins/bio/documentaries/wild-at-heart-the-plight-of-elephants-in-thailand/elephants-return-to-the-forest "Elephants Return to the Forest"], ''American Museum of Natural History''</ref><ref>[http://www.elephantreintroduction.org/ "Elephant Reintroduction Foundation"], ''Elephant Reintroduction Foundation website''</ref> and was released on the inaugural World Elephant Day.<ref>[http://worldelephantday.org/about/return-to-the-forest "Return to the Forest"], ''World Elephant Day website''</ref> The follow-up feature film [[When Elephants Were Young]], also narrated by [[William Shatner]], depicts the life of a young man and young elephant in Thailand.
== Issues ==
=== Poaching ===
The demand for [[ivory]], which is highest in [[China]],<ref>Damian Grammaticas, [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-26167893 "Uncovering China's illegal ivory trade"], ''BBC News'', 2014</ref><ref>Brendon Hong, [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/06/30/china-s-blood-ivory-bazaar.html "China's Blood Ivory Bazaar"], ''The Daily Beast'', 2014</ref><ref>Per Liljas, [http://world.time.com/2013/11/01/the-ivory-trade-is-out-of-control-and-china-needs-to-do-more-to-stop-it/ "The Ivory Trade Is Out of Control, and China Needs to Do More to Stop It"], ''Time Magazine'', 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.therakyatpost.com/life/2014/06/14/ivory-demand-china-thailand-led-killing-20000-african-elephants-last-year/ "Ivory demand in China, Thailand led to killing of 20,000 African elephants last year"], ''The Rakyat Post'', 2014</ref><ref>Paula Kahumbu, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2013/mar/04/china-message-consumers-ivory-trade "China must send a clear message to consumers on ivory trade"], ''The Guardian'', 2013</ref> leads to the illegal poaching of both African and Asian elephants. For example, one of the world's largest elephants, [[Satao (elephant)|Satao]], was recently killed for his iconic tusks.<ref>Christine Dell'Amore, [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/06/140616-elephants-tusker-satao-poachers-killed-animals-africa-science/ "Beloved African Elephant Killed for Ivory -- "Monumental" Loss"], ''National Geographic'', 2014</ref><ref>Mfonobong Nsehe, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/06/15/world-famous-elephant-satao-killed-by-poachers-in-kenya/ "World Famous Elephant 'Satao' Killed By Poachers In Kenya"], ''Forbes'', 2014</ref> Another iconic Kenyan elephant, Mountain Bull, was also killed by poachers, and with the street value for ivory now exceeding that of gold,<ref>Zoe Flood, [http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/06/15/satao-one-of-africas-largest-elephants-killed-by-poachers-for-ivory-tusks-weighing-more-than-45-kg/ "Satao, one of Africa's largest elephants, killed by poachers for ivory tusks weighing more than 45 kg"], ''National Post'', 2014</ref><ref>Ed Mazza, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/15/satao-the-elephant-killed_n_5497799.html "Satao The Elephant Killed By Poachers In Kenya"], ''The Huffington Post'', 2014</ref> African elephants face a poaching epidemic.<ref>Brian Jackman, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/safariandwildlifeholidays/10927089/Poaching-in-Africa-Selous-Game-Reserve-warning-highlights-scale-of-epidemic.html "Poaching in Africa: Selous Game Reserve warning highlights scale of epidemic"], ''Telegraph'', 2014</ref><ref>Melissa Hellmann, [http://time.com/2953056/african-elephant-poaching-soars-as-ivory-prices-triple-in-china/ "African-Elephant Poaching Soars as Ivory Prices Triple in China"], ''Time Magazine'', 2014</ref> Elephants are also poached for meat, leather, and body parts, with the illegal wildlife trade putting elephants increasingly in danger, because it is perceived to be a low risk and high profit endeavor.<ref>[http://www.traffic.org/home/2012/12/12/illegal-wildlife-trade-threatens-national-security-says-wwf.html/ "Illegal wildlife trade threatens national security, says WWF report"], ''TRAFFIC'', 2012</ref><ref>Melissa Hellmann, [http://time.com/2953056/african-elephant-poaching-soars-as-ivory-prices-triple-in-china/ "African-Elephant Poaching Soars as Ivory Prices Triple in China"], ''Time Magazine'', 2014</ref><ref>Alex Hofford, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/jul/21/-sp-endangered-species-on-sale-along-burmachina-border "Illegal wildlife trade along the Burma-China border - in pictures"], ''The Guardian'', 2014</ref>
=== Habitat loss ===
The loss of habitat due to [[deforestation]], increases in mining, and agricultural activities has become problematic, especially for Asian elephants.<ref>[http://www.amnh.org/explore/science-bulletins/bio/documentaries/wild-at-heart-the-plight-of-elephants-in-thailand/asian-elephants-threats-and-solutions "Asian Elephants: Threats and Solutions"], ''American Museum of Natural History''</ref><ref>Dave Armstrong, [http://www.earthtimes.org/nature/forest-loss-accelerates/2630/ "Forest loss accelerates"], ''The Earth Times'', 2014</ref> The fragmentation of habitat also creates isolation - this makes breeding more difficult, and allows poachers to find the elephants and set traps more easily.<ref>Kevin Heath, [http://wildlifenews.co.uk/2014/united-nations-launches-emergency-appeal-for-sumatran-elephants/ "United Nations launches emergency appeal for Sumatran elephants"], ''Wildlife News'', 2014</ref>
=== Human-elephant conflict ===
Human-elephant conflict is a significant concern, as human populations increase and forest cover decreases, forcing elephants into close proximity with human settlements.<ref>Sanjay Gubbi, M.H. Swaminath, H.C. Poornesha, Rashmi Bhat, and R. Raghunath, [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10531-014-0621-x "An elephantine challenge: human-elephant conflict distribution in the largest Asian elephant population, southern India"], ''Biodiversity and Conservation'', 2014</ref> Incidents include crop damage and economic losses, as well as both elephant and human casualties.<ref>Rabi Ahmed, Kushalappa, C.G., Ramesh, M.N., Sathish, B.N. and Nanaya Konerira, [http://www.scienceandnature.org/IJSN_Vol5%281%29M2014/IJSN-VOL5%281%2914-15.pdf "Human-elephant Conflict in Asian Context with Specific Reference to Crop Damage"], ''International Journal of Science and Nature'', 2014</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/5-jumbos-damage-crops-run-amuck-near-Soolagiri/articleshow/37109619.cms "5 jumbos damage crops, run amuck near Soolagiri"], ''The Times of India'', 2014</ref>
=== Mistreatment in captivity ===
A lack of legislation regarding the care and treatment of elephants in zoos, circuses, and tourism often leads to their mistreatment.<ref>Sangita Iyer, [http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/sangita-iyer/animal-cruelty-elephants_b_4536577.html "Seeing the Mistreatment of Elephants in India Was Haunting"], ''Huffington Post'', 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/animal-rights-activists-says-elephants-forced-do-handstands-chinese-zoo-1620234 "Animal Rights Activists Say Elephants Forced To Do Handstands By Chinese Zoo"], ''International Business Times'', 2014</ref><ref>Ed Stewart, [http://newswatch.nationalgeographic.com/2013/05/03/no-ethical-way-to-keep-elephants-in-captivity/ "No Ethical Way to Keep Elephants in Captivity"], ''National Geographic'', 2013</ref> Captivity can be a serious threat to elephants, and Asian elephants are often illegally captured in the wild and trafficked into the lucrative tourism industry.<ref>Richard Thomas, [http://wildlifenews.co.uk/2014/thailand-must-act-to-prevent-resurgence-of-illegal-wild-elephant-trade/ "Thailand must act to prevent resurgence of illegal wild elephant trade"], ''Wildlife News'', 2014</ref><ref>Lindsay Murdoch, [http://www.smh.com.au/environment/conservation/baby-elephants-captured-mistreated-to-supply-thailands-tourism-industry-20140709-zt0xw.html "Baby elephants captured, mistreated, to supply Thailand's tourism industry"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 2014</ref>
=== Celebrity voices === Many notable celebrities have spoken out about the urgency of elephant protection, including [[Leonardo DiCaprio]],<ref>[http://wildnet.org/updates/leonardo-dicaprio-foundation-donates-1-million-elephant-crisis-fund "Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation Donates $1 Million to Elephant Crisis Fund"], ''Wildlife Conservation Network'', 2014</ref> [[Kristin Davis]],<ref>Susanna Rustin, [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/oct/04/kristin-davis-elephant-ivory-blood-diamond "Kristin Davis: 'Ivory is basically a blood diamond'"], ''The Guardian'', 2012</ref> [[William Shatner]],<ref>William Shatner, [https://twitter.com/WilliamShatner/status/234662922830348289 "World Elephant Day is Today"], ''Twitter'', 2012</ref> [[Yao Ming]],<ref>Russell Flannery, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/russellflannery/2013/12/06/yao-ming-targets-elephant-poaching-ivory-trade-in-new-campaign-with-wildaid/ "Yao Ming Targets Elephant Poaching, Ivory Trade In New Campaign With WildAid"], ''Forbes'', 2013</ref> [[Prince William]],<ref>Sarah Morrison, [https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/prince-william-wants-all-royal-ivory-destroyed-9131140.html "Prince William wants 'all royal ivory destroyed'"], ''The Independent'', 2014</ref> [[Jorja Fox]],<ref>[http://www.ad-international.org/animal_rescues/go.php?id=2789&ssi=0 "Jorja Fox takes on the elephant abusers in new ADI video"], ''Animal Defenders International'', 2012</ref> [[Alec Baldwin]],<ref>Michelle Kretzer, [http://www.peta.org/blog/alec-baldwin-usda-seize-elephants/ "Alec Baldwin to USDA: Seize the Elephants"], ''PETA'', 2012</ref> [[Stephen Fry]],<ref>[http://www.elephantectivism.org/2013/12/stephen-frys-elephant-tweet.html "Stephen Fry's Elephant Tweet"], ''For Elephants International'', 2013</ref> [[Ashley Judd]],<ref>Nigel M. Smith, [http://www.indiewire.com/article/watch-ashley-judd-speaks-up-for-the-elephants-in-the-eyes-of-thailand-trailer "Watch: Ashley Judd Speaks Up for the Elephants in 'The Eyes of Thailand' Trailer"], ''IndieWire'', 2012</ref> [[Jada Pinkett Smith]],<ref>Jill Rosen, [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2012-03-06/entertainment/bal-jada-pinkett-smith-urges-srb-to-protect-elephants-20120306_1_ryan-o-doherty-elephants-pinkett-smith "Jada Pinkett Smith urges SRB to protect elephants"], ''The Baltimore Sun'', 2012</ref> [[Kathryn Bigelow]],<ref>https://variety.com/2014/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-campaigns-to-stop-elephant-poaching-with-short-film-1201374103/</ref> and politicians such as [[Barack Obama]],<ref>Melissa Mahony, [http://www.salon.com/2014/02/17/elephant_in_the_room_no_more_obama_bans_ivory_sales_partner/ "Elephant in the room no more: Obama bans ivory sales"], ''Salon'', 2014</ref> and [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] and [[Chelsea Clinton]].<ref>Rhett A. Butler, [http://news.mongabay.com/2014/0613-elephants-clinton-wcs-gala.html "Chelsea, Hillary Clinton urge action to save elephants"], ''mongabay.com'', 2014</ref><ref>Philip Mansbridge, [http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/philip-mansbridge/elephants-world-elephant-day_b_3739095.html "Is This Year's World Elephant Day the Last Chance for Elephants?"], ''The Huffington Post'', 2013</ref>

'''ZC Excess Futsal Club''' was a [[Malta|Maltese]] [[futsal]] club based in [[Bidnija]], last time known as '''Excess RP Bidnija''' after a merger with another local club '''RP Bidnija''' in 2011.
It is one of the most successful Maltese futsal clubs having won three [[Maltese Futsal League|national leagues]] and one [[Maltese Futsal Cup|cup]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.futsalplanet.com/story/story-national-02.asp?paeseclub=112|title=National futsal championship and cup winners|work=futsalplanet.com|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en}}</ref>
In 2010, Excess became the first Maltese side to win a competitive European futsal game when they beat [[Albania]]’s [[Futsal Klub Tirana|KF Tirana]]. They then drew with eventual group winners [[Ilves FC]] from a [[Finland|Finnish]] city [[Tampere, Finland|Tampere]], to finish third in the preliminary round [[2010-11 UEFA Futsal Cup|tournament]] in [[Cospicua]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110730/football/Excess-RP-Bidnija-target-improved-Euro-showing.377973|title=Excess RP Bidnija target improved Euro showing|work=timesofmalta.com|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en}}</ref>
==Achievements==
'''Maltese First Futsal Division''': [[2009-10 Maltese Futsal Premier League|2009-10]], [[2010-11 Maltese Futsal Premier League |2010-11]], [[2011-12 Maltese Futsal Premier League |2011-12]]
'''Maltese Futsal Cup''': [[2011-12 Maltese Futsal Cup|2011-12]]
